reviewText: No issues.
Purchased this for my device, it worked a advertised. You can never have too much phone memory, since I download a lot of stuff this wa a no brainer for me.
it work a expected. I should have sprung for the higher capacity. I think it made a bit cheesier than the earlier versions; the paint look not a clean a before

This think ha worked out great.Had a diff. bran 64gb card and if went south after 3 months.This one ha held up pretty well since I had my S3, now on my Note3.*** update 3/21/14I've had this for a few month and have had ZERO issue's since it wa transferred from my S3 to my Note3 and into a note2. This card is reliable and solid!Cheers!

Bought it with Retail Packaging, arrived legit, in a orange envelope, english version not asian like the picture shows. arrived quickly, bought a 32 and 16 both retail packaging for my htc one sv and Lg Optimus, both card in working order, probably best price you'll get for a nice sd card

It's mini storage. It doesn't do anything else and it's not supposed to. I purchased it to add additional storage to my Microsoft Surface Pro tablet which only come in 64 and 128 GB. It doe what it's supposed to and SanDisk ha a long standing reputation that speaks for itself.

I have it in my phone and it never skip a beat. File transfer are speedy and have not had any corruption issue or memory fade issue a I would expect from the Sandisk brand. Great card to own. Why entrust your precious file to a slightly cheaper piece of crap? If you lose everything can you forgive yourself for not spending the extra couple buck on a trusted product that go through good QA?

It's hard to believe how affordable digital ha become. 32 GB in a device one quarter the sie of postage stamp would have been science fiction le than a generation ago.I picked this up for portable music when I didn't want to schlep (or risk) a phone or iPod. Works great with all SD card readers.Select with confidence.
Works in a HTC Rezound. Was running short of space on a 64GB Sandisk so I ordered this when it came out, fast and no issues.
in my galaxy s4, super fast card, and am totally happy, not happy having to still type to fill the required word though

I like this SD Card because it can take music video downloads, personal videos, files,docs, and multimedia image with a fast transfer rate of Class 10 speed. It can take game with large file very easily and still have enough space for apps. It"s great for video camera and camcorder with the supplied adapter. Fits very easily into smartphones and tablet SD Card slots. I recommend this 32GB SD Card to everyone.

It works, but file writes are a bit slower than expected on a USB3 reader.Also, both read and writes are FASTER with the card inside the standard-size SD adapter (15 MB/s v 10 write; 45 MB/s v 22 MB/s read) on the same card reader. Can't figure why...
THE NAME OF ITSELF SPEAKS OUT. GO SANDISK GO!
Solid SDHC card that is fast (at reading and writing) fast (for recording video and pics), ha great capacity, and is reasonably priced. I have had no issue with it.Overall, highly recommend.
Heard that the card's write speed is insufficient, however I have used it extensively and haven't had a single problem with it!!

I bought this to use with my go pro hero 3 black edition. It requires a class 10 MicroSDXC card. So far I've had no issue with it. Fast read/write, came with adapter, small packaging, but that's all it needed! Comes with a nice hard plastic case to keep both dry and together if needed.

got this because i had a 2 GB one that filled up. i kept getting the insufficient disk space on my phone. my kid take my phone and do selfies. mostly my daughter. I had to get a bigger card. the 2GB one wa a carry over from an old phone.needless to say this wa sweet. plenty of space. and i dont have to delete picture anymore. well for now at least.my daughter love selfies.

Class 10 Speed Rating for Seamless Full HD VideoThe SanDisk Ultra UHS-I card feature a Class 10 and UHS Speed Class 1 (U1) rating, the highest video performance available for recording uninterrupted Full HD** video.Flawless App PerformanceThis card can retrieve stored data almost instantly, thanks to it up to 30MB/s read capability and fast bus interface. The SanDisk Ultra microSDHC and microSDXC UHS-I card offer faster app loading and smoother, more fluid app performance.Storage Capacities Up to 64GBThis card ha plenty of room to accommodate Full HD videos, MP3s, apps, and other memory-intensive mobile files. Available in size up to 64GB, it can store all the apps, music, and video you want.Android App for Easy File ManagementThe included SanDisk Memory Zone app let you easily view, access, and backup all of your digital file from your phone's memory, additional memory card, and cloud service all in one convenient place. Using the app, you can easily move file from your card to a number of cloud storage services.Durable DesignSanDisk Ultra UHS-I memory card can capture memory from -13 to 185 degree Fahrenheit with a shockproof, waterproof, and X-ray-proof design. Your mobile device may not survive, but your SanDisk memory card will.

The read and write speed are better than the Samsung SD card that I had previously. I would not hesitate to buy another one of these great Micro SD card from SanDisk. I also own their Clip plus MP3 player and it work very well. I think I'm becoming a fan of the SanDisk products.
This work with the NL1520. No video stuttering like with the 64gb. Blah blah blah blah to fill in the rest.

Works a expected. High transfer speed. Nice to have extra microSD adapter lying around since I always seem to misplace them. Mainly bought it to use in my Nikon DSLR since I can put the card directly into my (CM modded) Nook HD+ tablet in the field and view my image on a larger screen.

Works great in a Samsung Galaxy S3. Formatted straight away, full size there. I can't really tell the speed difference between this one and a slower card it replaced. I guess the IO in the phone can't take advantage.
SanDisk never disappoints. As always SanDisk product are worth every penny. Nice product and quality and work great. I recommend this product to everyone.
Good price, work flawless in my Samsung S4! Normal SanDisk quality! That is why I go with this brand and only this brand..
San disk is hard to beat. You will pay more for the brand but you get a quality product. Would purchase again.
Installed in my Blackberry Q10 SQN100-1 and formatted. Works just fine. Plenty of storage space for picture and video of my son at the park.

I just received my card, it is the class 10 64GB with the correct serial#SDSDQUA-064G-A11A. I received it in an unopened SanDisk packaging. I am going to use it on my HTC Rezound, I hope it works. From what I have read, it will work after reformatting the disk. I will update this review if I have any issue using it, if not, my rating will remain unchanged...

Stuck it in my S2, formatted in settings, work great! Already filled with music, pic and videos... Get this card, format it right, and you'll have no problems. If your phone won't do it right, should have got a Samsung! haha...
I purchased two of these one for my Samsung tablet and one for my samsung galaxy note. Great hardware that is truly speedy, responsive and meet my needs!

As advertised, spec match. As long a the device you a using it in can handle it (i.e. USB 3.0, not some crapple bs) it delivers the advertised speed. P.S. The speed is READ, not WRITE, but you knew that, right?
This item is great! I can't believe how small it is. Imagine 64gb this size back in the 70's when they had whole building full of computer that couldn't pack this much space! Great item.

I've been trying for a while to get a hold of a 32GB Micro SD for my phone and tablet. It's pretty fast compared to the 16GB card I've been using. I really saw the performance boost with my phone, which I have many apps, pictures, music, and other document on. The phone boot fully stable in about 2 min a apposed to 5-6 mins. My computer also can write to these card much faster than the 16GB one I wa using. If you phone, tablet or any other device can support it I recommend you purchase these. Also you pay like half the price using Amazon a opposed to other retail store who's price is at least double or more. I've seen these same card going for about $72 in my area.

I bought 2 of those SanDisk 32 GB microSD , used them on my Galaxy Note and Galaxy S4First one , my phone started saying it wa removed , then recognize it again :) then diedI thought it's just a luck , plugged in the 2nd one :) stayed for about 2 month and died suddenly ! and lost everythingnever buying from SanDisk again .. ever

I've got a couple of these in varying sizes. I've had no problem and no complaint about speed. I always end up buying more because the price are so low for what you get.
I only had 8 gig of memory on my Note 2 and wa running out of room. Now I have so much memory space available I don't know what to do with it.
Bought it for my Surface Pro. I've had it in there for a few month and I've had no problems. Very fast and stable.
I would recommend this card to everyone.Data Transfer speed - excellent with this card on my Galaxy S2. Didn't need to format the card or anything. I am 100% satisfied.

I bougth this micro SD card after some trubles with other that i got from Kingston, i can tell that SanDisk is other quality, this is the best, my i9300 phone can read a 64GB very fast, the dta transfer speed from my pc to my is amazing, if you are looking for additional storage to you phone, for music, picture and other type of files, this is for you.Pros-Very good quality material of construction-Amazing speedUpdate after one year this memory is damaged I can not delete or put new file on it, I can not format this memory, I tried to format with my phone, with my pc, with a camera and nothing, now this is like a 64gb cd, the data in the memory is only available to read but I can not move, or delete it, I bought this memory to be used to backup all my data of my android device but now is only a readable memory I can not write data on it any more, I hope sandisk make a better product in the future!!! Total disagree I will buy a Samsung memory card expected a better quality.
Using this in a contout gps camera, don't waste your time buying any other brand it will be a waste. Buy the best to start with.

This is a fantastic little drive, ha all the gigabyte it says, work in all way I can discern and I use it to hold the flac recording I play on my excellent Fiio X5 digital audio player. This is the real thing and not one of the fake that, evidently, are out there.

If you want something that can transfer file Photos, Videos, and Music faster this is the Micro SD card for you. Now I will say this there are faster card out there but not at this price. It doe the job and the price wa right. It came quickly so I'm very happy for the purchase. I would recommend it and would but it again.

I got a replacement card, but I had to send in the old one, giving up any chance of recovering it contents. The new one's worked fine, but failing after 3 month in inexcusable.

A memory card either work or it doesn't. This wa always going to be a one star or five star review - no middle ground.The adapter is a nice bonus too, though I don't think I have anything to use it with.

I purchased this card to use in my ContourROAM2 and it work great. All I had to do wa put the card in the camera, format it, and I wa good to go. It allows me to easily record hour of 720p/60fps video without running out of space or slowing down.

everything about it wa great, except for the adapter. It wa to tight i had to use a tool to take it back out of the adapter causing me to chip it. so my fault i guess, but i also bought a 16gb version and the adapter for that one wa fine.

Liked the first one I purchased so much, I bought a second one. Very, very fast read and write speed at a good price, plus SanDisk ha the best software and device compatibility. Forget thumb drive - this is your most flexible, durable option. Use direct in your tablet or smart phone and/or buy a decent usb card reader you can load this in and, voila, instant super-speedy, upgradeable thumb drive. Works great in my tablet and in my newer card reader - and still kick the butt of every thumb drive I know of even when used with my old plastic USB 2.0 card reader held together with scotch tape, lol. Have purchased several microSD card since they first came out, from 2GB to 32GB, and all still work fine - I cannot say the same re the thumb drive I purchased during that same time period.One point - beware of counterfeits. Samsung is the number one brand so, unfortunately, they get counterfeited a LOT. So check review and only buy from a reliable seller. I suggest buying direct from Amazon (or Memory Mogul) - I have purchased from both with no issues.
Really you can't say anything bad about it. Does what it says. Super fast and great storage size for lot of movie and such.

Used in my phone it's plenty fast and work just like it should. Unexpectedly come with mini and full SD card size adapters, which is nice. "Fool-proof" packaging or whatever it was, that wa laughable. Packaging wa decent it just shouldn't have bragged about being impossible to mess up when I messed it up.

This is just the standard micro SD card i would recommend this to anyone. i purchased this for my dad who is using it to expand the memory on his tablet! it shipped fast and is a slight bit cheaper than in the store i believe.

I ordered this for my new Samsung Galaxy note II, and it work awesome! Installed it, and had no problems. I loaded all my music on it, and didn't even scratch the surface of the capacity of this card! I shouldn't ever have to worry about running outta room with this card. Highly recommended for any smartphone user!
Great Deal and much faster file movement.Definitely worth the purchase and sandisk ha proved why they have good products.

You'll pay $10 more for these anywhere else. I wa initially leery of buying another SD card on amazon. 4 year ago I did so, and the card wa a fake (said it had 32 gig when plugged into the computer, but you could only load about 11 onto it, and it would say "full." Apparently there's a way to fool your computer into thinking there's more space than there is, and this is what the fake/counterfeit card will do).Not so with this one. It's the real deal, genuine SanDisk, and contains a many GB a it say it does. I'm a very pleased customer.
Use this in my Samsung Galaxy S4. Have had it for almost a year now, no problems, really expands your memory capabilities, easy enough to install.

32gb of storage for my new Asus tablet, what's not to love? I can't imagine paying more for the model with the upgraded storage, especially since it's usually like $100 more. This thing wa cheap and work great.
excellent quality, excellent speed. no complaint here. very easy to use, reliable and the red stripe on the front make it easy to find on a crowded desk

Purchase for HP tablet to have more memory for music download, pictures, and video. Have enough room to store and some memory left over.
Can there be anything wrong with a sandisk product? the item read to it sooooo quickly, I am quite happy,

It will not freeze because it can move the MB/s fast enough. Lesser speed card will freeze or will say waiting for camera and you will miss the moment. Its also a Sandisk which is a name you can trust when it come to memory cards.

All though it state 16gig it only ha 14.8gig available but I know that happens and expected it, keep this in mind if your wanting more storage you might want to order the 32gig card. It wa exactly what i expected and needed so no complaints.
doe the job a advertised.if you need extra memory on your phone/tablet or whatever device, this is bext buy(price/quality)
Needed for my cell phone - work perfectly. SanDisk ha never been a disappointment in the 30 plus year I've been in IT/computer work.
Priced right, this memory card also read and writes fast. It's a noticeable difference over cheaper cards. I put it in my phone and plan to buy another one for my tablet.

work great on my sprint htc evo 4g lte. Formatted w/ fat32 so of course the maximum file size is 4gb meaning no full length hidef movies. However, this isn't a problem; I bought the card for putting a music library on my phone.Like all class 10 micro-sdhc cards, it doe NOT do 10MB/s, but it's closer than any other class 10 card I've ever tried. Most do 3-4MB/s. Kingston 32GB did 7MB/s. This card doe about 8-9MB/s.Can't wait till 128GB and 256GB card become available and affordable.

**Update 6.24.14**My 128 GB card stopped allowing writes via any of my card-readers on a Windows PC--either when it wa inside any of several full-size SD card adapter (with the write-protect tab in either position) or plugged directly into the microSD slot of the reader. MicroSD card have no write-protect tab, so I wa quite surprised and worried by this. After failing to find any workable solution by searching online, I finally put it in my Chromebook and created a new folder on it there, then stuck it back in my Windows PC and it no longer gave me a write-protect error. If anyone ha a similar problem, I'd recommend doing something similar by putting it in any other PC, laptop, camera, etc you have available and try writing to it there.----------------------------------------------This portion of my review is necessarily being written a an update to my original review of the 64 GB version of this card, since Amazon disallows multiple review for what they consider the same item. This portion concern the 128 GB version of this card:I don't need a fast card, so the speed on this card were not that important, besides which my test PC is not exactly high-end. Therefore I didn't count off for the speed result I got below, using a USB 2.0 card adapter, but I thought they might be relevant to some readers. While the card did reach the Class-10 and/or UHS-I requirements, it came in at under 2/3 of the claimed "read speed up to 30 MB/s for fast file transfer." Then again, running on a second PC using a different USB 2.0 card reader, none of the speed even hit 5 MB/s, so this seems to be highly system-dependent.I only just got the card this week, and so far it work on *select* SDXC-compatible device and exFAT-compatible operating systems: some SDXC-compatible devices, such a the Panasonic HDC-TM40, do not allow card larger than 64 GB (for whatever reason); this wa stated in the manual, and I've confirmed this card is recognized a broken/corrupt/unusable in that device, whereas 64 GB exFAT card work fine. The 128 GB work fine (with original exFAT formatting) in my Toshiba Excite 7.7 Android tablet, and (predictably) not at all in my non-SDXC-compatible Galaxy Note 2 (though it possibly would if reformatted to FAT32, since a 64 GB card in FAT32 work fine there).I'll update my review to reflect any problems, issues, etc that I notice in the coming day & weeks.-----------------------------------------------------------------------CrystalDiskMark 3.0.3 (C) 2007-2013 hiyohiyoCrystal Dew World : [url removed a per Amazon rules]-----------------------------------------------------------------------* MB/s = 1,000,000 byte/s [SATA/300 = 300,000,000 byte/s]Sequential Read : 18.694 MB/sSequential Write : 11.921 MB/sRandom Read 512KB : 18.502 MB/sRandom Write 512KB : 0.680 MB/sRandom Read 4KB (QD=1) : 3.339 MB/s [ 815.1 IOPS]Random Write 4KB (QD=1) : 1.581 MB/s [ 386.1 IOPS]Random Read 4KB (QD=32) : 3.151 MB/s [ 769.4 IOPS]Random Write 4KB (QD=32) : 1.564 MB/s [ 381.8 IOPS]Test : 1000 MB [G: 0.0% (0.0/119.1 GB)] (x5)Date : 2014/04/24 16:53:49OS : Windows XP Professional SP3 [5.1 Build 2600] (x86)-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------The following is my original review of the 64 GB version of this card, published April 24, 2013:This is a high-quality card. I've used it in a variety of devices, through multiple reader on different pcs, in an HD camcorder using a micro to full-sized SD adapter, and I've never once had a problem with it. It even work at full capacity in *some* microSDHC-only device once it reformatted to FAT32 (such a my SanDisk Clip+ FLAC player and supposedly even PSPs via a proper adapter, though I haven't yet tested my PSP). I keep anticipating someone coming out with a card with equal or better capacity and speed at a comparable price, but I haven't seen one yet. If these were cheaper, I'd have several by now.Make sure your device can handle micro or full-sized SDXC cards, or is one of those rare gem that state they support only a high a SDHC but have been tested to work with SDXC card such a this one once they've been manually reformatted to FAT32.
Works great in the phone and the wife love it, we got a second for her mom and she is storing lot of picture and video on it

I loaded this card up with home movie for my Samsung Galaxy Tab 2. The copy process from computer to card wa fast. There are no skip in the movie quality and I have plenty of room left to go. Wish I had bought another for more collections.

Bought this for my S3 and loaded it with 4 season of Futurama, 5 full length HD movies, several documentaries, and a dozen or so 30 minute comedy show with plenty of room left over for pictures, etc...Only slight nitpick is when booting up into recovery mode on the S3 it will not recognize the card. Wanted to update the phone to the latest version of Android and it would not see it. Had to resort to a 2GB MicroSD I had laying around. That wasn't a SD card issue but I thought I would throw that in.

I purchased this after my wife and I bought our Samsung Galaxy S4 to store all the music, picture and videos. The S4 camera is capable of capturing 16-megapixels photo so the 16GB microSD that I had will not suffice. As a matter of fact I've already exhausted the remaining space on the card so this 64GB will allow me to take more photo (of our son).
Great storage, ha not failed yet after about a year of usage.
Since the wife is using it and it is not causing any problems, then it must be functioning normally. Looks good so far.
Class 10 speed are the only way to fly and with 29.71GB of usable space I think I should be good for a while.
The subject say it all. Does what it's supposed to do ... at a great price. When it's on sale, buy it.

Lot of question about this memory card fitting the Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 10.1 tablet. It fit and work no problem at all. The only thing is that after installing, instead of showing 64GB available, it only show 59GB.Tried formatting the card but with same results.Have no idea if this is a limit set by the the Galaxy Tab 3 tablet, or is it just "normal" to buy 64GB and get le than that.As this is surely not a problem coming from the Sandisk memory card, my rating is a 5-STAR. Excellent price, work great, and very quick delivery.

When it come to any kind of flash storage SanDisk ha always been my go to brand because they sell quality item and stand by them if there's a problem. So a usual no complaint here, it work a descried and I haven't have any issues. Both read and write speed are right where the spec say they should be.
High speed, high capacity of storage. Great durability. I use in my phone and in my digital camera. Work very good
THis memory help me to keep all what I want to keep on my cell phone.It is a good brand and it on the right price.

I bought this SD card for my android phone thinking that a class 10 will be faster and more reliable than others. it turn out, the difference in class doesn't really matter at least for Android phones. didn't really worth the price difference
The SanDisk 32GB Micro SD Class 10 is a reliable SD card with amazing transfer speeds. There is no noticeable lag transfering even the largest RAW image to it. Hadn't had any problem with it.
good card. work a describes. haven't had any issue with it or going pas metal detectors. no lost file or missing files.
Bought this to store music on my phone. Works flawlessly after three month so far, no problems.In my card reader, I average 6-8 megabyte read and write to it.

I'm amazed. I ordered this from Amazon on Tuesday morning, and it arrived with Wednesday's mail. VERY impressive service from Amazon!As ha already been reported, the card format out to > 59 Gb, and it performs perfectly in my Samsung Galaxy S III (which is also new). Using two card reader on a fast PC, I transferred everything from my old 16GB card to the new 64 GB card in le time than it took to walk to the kitchen and get a cup of coffee. So I think the Class 10 rating is correct on the card.Once I have some experience with the card in the phone, I'll benchmark the card and I'll also benchmark operation such a internally backing up my Android phone to the card. Then I'll update this review with some accurate numerical data. But in the mean time on first look, the person who said that the S 3 ha problem with anything faster than class 6 may not have been correct - a full backup of the phone to the card wa significantly faster than the backup with the old 16GB class 6 card. Again no benchmark yet but once I have them I'll include them here.Right now I'm very happy with this card and I'm really impressed - both with the card and with the unbelievably quick service from Amazon (and I'm in Atlanta where shipment like this one often take the full 3 day to arrive).
Excellent, one of the best, can't go wrong with this card, class 10 is necessary and show noticeable but not significant improvement over class 4

I bought the 64GB MicroSD card at Best Buy because I needed one for my Microsoft Surface Pro. It provides all the space I need and for people who need a lot of space (videos, Quick Books, picture editing, games, etc.) this card is the one for you. If you don't need that much space, consider buying one for cheaper with a little le memory.NOTE: Be aware that this is a MicroSDXC format card. While most new computer support this format, many of the older computer do not (This includes all but a few tablet and smartphones). Before buying this, MAKE SURE your computer, tablet, or smartphone is compatible. If it is not, it will not work, period. For others who claim that the card doesn't work no matter what they try, chance are their machine cannot support MicroSDXC format.

I got this because I just couldn't pas up the deal, $17.99. It ha been incredibly fast in my HTC Sensation 4g. Pictures are taken and saved instantaneously. Only had it a few days, but have been very happy. Shipping wa fast and the packaging wa easy to open which is always great in my book. Only issue I had wa I had to format it on my computer first before my phone wa able to recognize it.
You get a lot of storage at a small price. the micro sd with adapter, class 10 so it's fast . I am happy with this purchase and You will be too. I hope this review is helpful!

The Ultra micro SDHC wa fine once I got it working. Neither the packaging nor the Sansa Clip player inform the user that the player need to be totally off before the microcard is inserted. If not, the unit will not read the card! Otherwise? Love it and the storage for even 16 GB, let alone 32, is tremendous...

I upgraded to this after the price dropped. I originally had a 16gig sandisk card and it wa in my mytouch 4g. I found toward my mytouch 4g's end of life that space is running low. So when I got my Galaxy S3 I bought this card. It work flawlessly. I highly recommend it. Now error what so ever. Super fast transfer rate.

This item wa priced right and fit right into my cell phone without any issues. Does what it is suppose to do and I don't know what else I could say. Being a class 10 it is suppose to be plenty fast for cell phone use which I am sure speed up camera use to some degree. Has worked well and the shipping wa fast.

I got this memory card for my Samsung Galaxy S3. I wa running out of room on my Sandisk 32gb Class 4 micro sd card. I also wanted a faster and more durable card. I wa hopping to put lot of medium on it. In addition to nandroid backup and custom roms. I later found out that since this card is formatted in ex-fat it would not work to make nandroid backup or flash custom roms. Most custom recovery and custom rom dont work with ex-fat. So my only choice wa to format the card to fat 32, which meant I couldn't put any file larger than 4gb on it. Besides that this card is great and very reasonable price of $50. If your some one who doesn't root their phone or put custom roms, nandroid backup or put file larger than 4gb than this will not affect you. This memory card is fast and provides the most storage you can put on your mobile device at this time. The card is also water proof, shock proof and come with lifetime warranty. Ive never had any issue with sandisk memory card or usb flash drives. They last a really long time.
Using the included adaptor on my MacBook Pro to transfer files, I wa impressed with the speed of this card.
Got this to store movie and music on my Samsung Note III.Not much to say about a memory card except that it work a expected.

I purchased this version to expand memory on my 16gb android tablet. Nothing fancy but it doe the job. No problem and it played back flawlessly all the file I transferred.There are so many different microSD card out now but if you see this on sale then you might want to consider it instead of cheaper no-name brand.

Update: providing an update with regard to SanDisk support.I bought the memory card in Aug 2012 (see original review below). In May of 2013 while on my cruise to Alaska the card went bad. During the sailing out of San Francisco it wa fine a I used it to take a panorama shot of the Golden Gate Bridge. For most of the cruise I wa using my DSLR but the next time I wanted to use my cell phone, the phone told me I had no memory card loaded. Any way, tested the card on my laptop when I got back and it couldn't recognize it. I contacted SanDisk via email and provide them copy of my receipt from Amazon along with the serial number on the back of the card (very hard to read) and no problems; they told me to send them back the card and they sent me a brand new card which is now still functioning in my cell phone. Great support provide by SanDisk. No hassle a long a you can provide proof of purchase (easy to do since Amazon keep my entire purchase history/invoices online). One reason I buy directly from Amazon itself v other vendor (either on Amazon or elsewhere on the Internet) is that I have confidence that the memory card sold by Amazon itself are genuine. there may be incredible deal elsewhere on the internet but in some case the deal are too good to be true and counterfeit card are being sold.Original review:Just received this today. Removed it from the packaging and inserted it into my Samsung Galaxy S3 (Verizon) and powered the unit back up and the storage wa available. No formatting required. Worked the first time out. Settings showed 29.71GB of total space (32GB version) and 29.71GB of free space. I like the fact that a SD adapter came with it. Should I ever need to insert the card into my laptop it will come in handy. (yes I can plug my phone directly to my laptop but if I ever swap this 32GB card out of my phone and replace it with a 64GB version, I can use this 32GB version via the adapter for other purposes.)
Still don't feel is very fast or is just my phone, I guess I will need to remove it and run some R/W tests. Still Its ok.

I bought 64GB version of the card to use with GoPro Hero 3 black edition. It didn't work out. The card worked OK if camera wa set to resolution with lower bit rates. E.g. worked fine in 720p with protune on, or 1080p with protune off. However, in 1080p with protune on (bitrate is just shy of 6 MB/s in this mode -- much higher then with protune turned off) it wa nothing but trouble. Camera would sometime work, and sometime randomly stop recording for no obvious reason. I first suspected camera, but testing with different SD cards, it ended up being SanDisk's card that wa at fault. My spare card, an old and cheap 16GB PNY (also class 10), worked just fine under same condition and with same camera settings.Once it wa obvious it wa problem with the card, I found people on GoPro's forum that had trouble with this specific card a well (well, you always find these only after you figure it out for yourself, right?). Anyhow, I did some speed test with the card by doing simple write of 1GB file full of zero using Unix dd utility to copy 1GB of zero from /dev/zero (where else would you find that many zero ;-) onto a file on the card. The result wa that on average, SanDisk's card would manage about 10.2 MB/s. Just barely above the bar for class 10 card. However, that wa average over 1GB. During the write test, the speed wa oscillating with many spike and drops. Drops were a low a 7MB/s. Uh. I thought write speed of class 10 card should never dip below 10 MB/s? For comparison, my old cheap class 10 PNY card wa chugging along at constant 13 MB/s under the same test. No spike and no drop in speed.The card will probably work fine in most devices, a bitrates when recording 1080p video are often low enough and/or camera might have huge buffer. But if you want to use it to record video at high bitrates, and your device doesn't have huge buffer to compensate for speed bump of this card, you may run into trouble. Be wary of using it in Hero3 in mode that have higher bit rate (e.g. 1080p with protune enabled).SanDisk's website list part number a SDSDQUI-064G with adapter, and SDSDQUA-064G without adapter. This conflict with product description on Amazon. While this is likely just Amazon not getting product description right again (a bit too common thing), it's interesting to note.[Update Apr 20 2013]:Some number from testing the card. The test is extremely simple. Write out 1GB of zero onto the card using standard Unix dd command to read 128KB block of zero from special device /dev/zero and write it onto the card. 128KB * 8192 = 1GB. dd display transfer stats once it finishes. While dd wa running, I run iostat in second terminal displaying 1 second interval stats a a measure of current speed. This wa done on the Mac. dd command line can be used as-is to repeat test on Linux system, however iostat command is different on Linux and would need to be modified slightly. I choose 128KB block size, a that seems to be what device driver merges sequential writes into anyhow. Using different block sizes, result are comparable.$ dd if=/dev/zero of=test bs=131072 count=81928192+0 record in8192+0 record out1073741824 byte transferred in 101.578307 sec (10570582 bytes/sec)So, 10 MB/s and all is good? Right? Wrong! iostat running in parallel with above dd command recorded this:$ iostat -d -w 1 disk2disk2KB/t tps MB/s123.11 76 9.12116.61 185 21.04122.94 49 5.88128.00 41 5.12128.00 89 11.11128.00 134 16.73128.00 69 8.61128.00 61 7.62128.00 99 12.36[ ... and so on until dd finish writing 1GB of zero to the card ... ]IMO, the last column should never dip under 10MB/s for card labeled class-10.For comparison, same test run against Samsung Pro 64GB micro-SD card:$ dd if=/dev/zero of=test bs=131072 count=81928192+0 record in8192+0 record out1073741824 byte transferred in 52.869111 sec (20309436 bytes/sec)$ iostat -d -w 1 disk2disk2KB/t tps MB/s125.30 138 16.86117.73 157 18.03123.04 150 18.00128.00 159 19.86128.00 156 19.47126.45 160 19.73128.00 150 18.72128.00 154 19.22128.00 153 19.11[ ... and so on until dd finish writing 1GB of zero to the card ... ]So, Samsung is on average 2x faster, but more importantly it's speed is much more constant. And critically important, it never dip under 10MB/s.

My Samsung Galaxy Note 2 came with 8 gig of internal memory. I discovered that apps can only be written to the internal 8 gig of memory so I didn't want to fill up the internal memory with pictures, videos, music, etc. I purchased the 64 GB San Disk Ultra MicroSDXC Class 10 card. I found a video on youtube to learn how to insert the card since I could find nothing on it in the phone's user guide. It's real easy. Turn the Note phone off. Remove the Note's back plate. You see a plaque saying SD card in the upper left quadrant of the phone. Simply place the microsd card face up with the metallic pin facing down and towards the right into the depressed slot area to the left of the SD card plaque. Then slowly and gently slide the microsd card under the plaque until it clicks. If it isn't in correctly, it will tend to move back out from under the plaque. Do not force. Replace the back plate on the phone. Turn the phone on. Go to settings, storage. At the bottom of the page, you will see SD Card. If the microsd card wa inserted correctly, you will see the additional GBs of storage displayed there. You will also see Reformat SD card and Remove SD card. Use these setting to erase data from the microsd card, and to remove it from the phone. Do not try to remove the microsd card from the phone without first activating the Remove SD Card setting. You can damage the card and the phone. The card came quickly and San Disk is a reliable brand. It's great to have the Class 10 rating too.

Initially when I inserted the card into the Samsung Galaxy S3 it recognized it but it wasn't able to format it correctly. Installed this in my Droid Bionic.I just backed up all my data using the included card reader adapter and the card reader slot on the laptop, and copied all data to a folder on my PC. In the past, I've bought lot of CF and SD card and USB keys. Years ago, I bought brand randomly until I had a failure with a particularly high-priced brand. At the time, these critter were tres chere, so I decided to standardize on WD because I'd never had a failure (except for hard drives, but that's a different topic).Now that the price per gig is le than I used to pay per meg, I still stick with WD because I'm using these card over long period of time and don't want to lose the data.I recognize that this is anecdotal and may or may not be in line with what Consumer Reports say or others' experience, but by now, I'm a mindless fan and frequently chant "Roll WiDe."Now, if only they would get rid of the anti-shoplifting packaging . . . .

I've purchased this MicroSD card back in January for use in my tablet and my Android smartphone. I wasn't absolutely certain if this would work in my Samsung Galaxy SIII (an SGH-I747M) from a regional carrier here in Alaska.I read several reviews, but took a chance the 64GB card would work in my device and wa pleased when it arrived.Opting for the "Frustration Free Package" it wa a very simple matter to open the little cardboard envelop to retrieve the contents. A side note here, I do appreciate the Amazon packaging for item such a this, where a clamshell type of container add no value...The card is well made and seems a quality product. Installed the card and it wa recognized instantly on boot. The full capacitywas recognized.Maybe I am old school when it come to memory cards, but I always format them in the device I intend on using them (at least initially.) In this case, there were no issues.While I haven't scientifically measured read / write speed of the card, performance is respectable. I have suffered no issuesrelated to the operation of the card.I would highly recommend this product if you are looking for this capacity and your device will accept the MicroSDXC format. To that end, several friend have purchased (and been satisfied) with this memory card in their devices.

I will keep it short and sweet for potential buyer looking for fact and not b.s.I own two of the 32gb size of these card for about 3 month now. They do work fairly well with cell phone and tablets, yet not so good with cameras, in fact these card failed to work with my GoPro Hero3 camera and the customer service rep from Gopro claimed (and I happen to agree with him) that this card is not a true class 10 card let alone UHS-1.Benchmarks with my evo 4g with all allocation size the write speed never passed beyond 8mb/s while read speed wondered around 25mb/s far below advertised speeds, well write speed arent technically advertised (probably because they are of class 4 level)Benchmarks with crystal mark reported speed even lower (due to adapter) with write speed around 6mb/s while read speed wondered around 20mb/s.Needless to say, if you are not worried about speed and only about storage, these are perfect. If you want to use them for shooting high definition raw footage however, I suggest you not to loose your money on this, because even if your write speed are around 10mb/s a the card begin to decay it will slow down to become useless.Again this review is based on GoPro camera and high definition raw recording.. For cell phone or for storage it work perfectly well with a bit of false advertisement..
Just what I needed for my digital music collection on my phone.

Not a fast a advertised most of the time, actually slowed down my Note 3 when I filled it with movie leaving only about 8gb free, switched to a faster card due to that, but it could also be the phone fault. All in all it's a good card with good speed and size for the money.

This is a great SD card, it's very fast and work well. I have been using it for my GoPro with no complaints.

This is a very fast microSD card compared to the class 4 speeds. It look nice and it works. This is the best accessory that you can buy for your smartphone! Simple explanation:1) I loaded all my HD movie onto this micro SD card, inserted it into my Samsung Galaxy S3, and it play them superbly without ANY delays, a it it up to 30mb/s read speed!2) The most important reason for this being the best accessory for your phone is to think about this: The premium you pay for an iPhone 64GB is $200. The price you pay for this 64GB micro SD card is $50 (depends on Amazon's pricing at the time). That mean you get the same thing for $150 less, AND you can interchange your SD card between device (if you buy a new tablet for example).No brainer.Note that it read only at 10mb/s, so a 7GB HD movie will take about 10 - 15 minute to load up.
This is the biggest memory card I have at 32 gig. It work fine! I am using it on an 8 inch Dell tablet with Windows 8 and a solid state 8 gig hard drive.

This is great if you are trying to shoot something in motion. A fast SD card is essential for this feature to work properly.

When I first got this card, it worked perfectly in my Galaxy S3 phone. Then, I rooted the phone and installed the Cyanogen Mod ROM to gain additional feature not available from my carrier. You'll find the card roomy and fast.
Worked fine in my Samsung S4 for one year. Then it stopped allowing writing to the card. Would not format even on a PC or with another device. The data is still there but cannot be erased.

Works fine in my Sony RX100 using the provided adapter, but who would expect otherwise. Bought the more expensive micro with adapter rather than full size SD so that I can move it to other device that take micro SD.Prime shipping arrived in one day.

Works Great! I wa running out of room on my 32GB card on my Galaxy Note 3. This solved my problem nicely! Now I have enough space for movies, music and photo on my device! I don't think I will be running out of space for a while!

Bought this card to use with my Samsung Galaxy Tab2 7in tablet, based on others who have reported getting it to work in their Galaxy Tab 2.Bottom line, you gotta reformat this card a FAT32 with 32kb sector to work in the Galaxy Tab 2, and that requires jumping thru some hoop a Win6/Vista doe not even offer the choice to format a FAT32, only a NTFS or exFAT, neither of which will work with the Galaxy Tab 2 (Android v4.04) You have to use 3rd party software to accomplish this. A FREE solution is the EaseUS Partition Master free software you can download from cnet or direct from EaseUS. I had a commercial package already installed (Acronis DiskDirector) that I used.Once fomatted a FAT32 with 32kb sectors, the card is recognized AND all the space is seen and useable.Highly recommended if you need the space. I would assume that this would also make LARGER microSDXC card work a wellJohn

I got this for my cell phone and it wa easy to put in. I have had not problem with it at all, it's been in my phone for a few month now and it's great having all the extra storage for pictures. I got it on time and it wa so easy to remove from the package.

If your card get hot enough to be painful, it is defective and you need to contact SanDisk!From my experience, the larger micro SDs run hot on format and writing, but not to the pain threshold!I purchased one of these card to use in a camera and Android tablet. Great read speed but write speed wa okay. Used card for about two week and then all my file disappeared! Tried to format the card and three different computer with XP, Windows, and Linux couldn't format it. The camera and tablet couldn't format it. I RMA'd it and got another because SanDisk is a good brand. I did notice that when formatting or writing the card it got hot, very hot.Second card didn't last 24 hour and had the exact same symptom a the first card. Write a file or format it resulted in the card getting hot enough to reach the pain threshold. I called up SanDisk and while explaining this wa the second card I'd received with the exact same symptoms, when I mentioned it getting hot, they immediately issued me an RMA. They said they were told to issue an RMA the moment they heard a card ran hot.Smaller SanDisk micro SD's or regular SD's I have or use don't do this. I think SanDisk ha an issue with this card.The last 4 digit of the part number refer to the date code and origin of the card. Both card had different date and origin codes.
Great card for a great price read and write speed are on par with what is posted on the specification detail report.

Does not work. I have a card purchased at Best Buy that look identical side by side. BUT! I originally bought a Samsung equivalent and then my phone wa stolen, so I made the switch. I have done some research and realized the class 10 and the SDXC are very important a it is the quickest rate of transfer. However when you read Samsung's description and this one, Samsung claim 80 mbps and SanDisk ha 30 mbps, after using both they are identical. The class and the sdxc are the most important, they are almost absolutely identical. Samsung's equivalent is $65 and this wa under $50. I haven't noticed a bit of difference, besides that maybe this mircosd card is a bit quicker and easier to move file around. I store a lot on my phone, which is a Samsung Note 3, this work beautifully.

It is so hard to imagine that you can have 32 GB is something smaller than a postage stamp, yet here it is.I bought this card to work with my Call of Duty Ghosts Tactical Camera and it work perfectly. The camera came with a 4 G card which I filled in just over an hour at the local Kart track. I missed the last bit of our race due to insufficient capacity. The battery wa still going strong so I needed more card for recording my adventures.This card fit the bill nicely.As a UHS Speed Class 1 (roughly equiv Class 10) card this SD card is quite capable of any photographic or video need up to Full HD (not 2k or 4k). I use a similar card in my Canon 60D and am able to hold around 700 raw images, and a few hour of HD video.Here are some benchmark for comparison including this card.MacBook Pro Retina SSD430 MB/s write323 MB/s readGeneric Class 6 4GB (Came with Ghost Camera)9.8 MB/s write21 MB/s readSanDisk Extreme Class 10 8GB21 MB/s write23 MB/s readThis Card San Disk Ultra UHC 112 MB/s write45 MB/s readWhat doe this mean? It mean that you should have no trouble recording HD video reliably with this card. Your camera will be able to save picture quickly to this card so it is ready to take the next shot. If you fill the card completely it will take roughly 12 minute to copy all the data off of the card, assuming the device you are copying to can keep up.The test were done in the built in SD card drive of the MacBook Pro using the included SD Card Adapter.Based on my tests, I would say that if you don't really need a Micro SD, then you should buy a standard SD card, your performance might be better and the price should be lower. However, if you think you need or might need a Micro SD down the road, this is a suitable solution.

This card wa used in a phone without a large amount of write stress (which doe shorten the life of the card - it wa not written to over and over in the phone).The card is now totally unwriteable - on a Mac, a Linux machine, or the phone - writes all "seem" to succeed but even low-level reformats don't actually *do* anything - the exact same file are there after every change, untouchable and frozen forever.10 month of use out of a memory card and then a really weird failure like this (neither the Mac, Linux machine, or phone report any error) is not acceptable quality from SanDisk.

We have bought two of these. You get an open slot with your smartphone and you should use it. Pictures, movies, and music will fill up your primary device storage in a heartbeat. Further, it is a good practice to have your "personal" stuff, like the thing I just mentioned, saved to an external drive so a to not be in the mix should the horrific happen and you have to get your phone wiped.Word to the wise: ENCRYPT YOUR STORAGE, both Primary Device and External SD. For the Samsung Galaxy S4 (at least), that, in turn, requires that you use a phone unlock code of at least SIX characters, with at least one of them being non-numeric. I know this can appear to be a pain in the butt, but the first time your device is ganked and you aren't panicking because your stuff is encrypted, you'll thank me. Nekkid picture aren't the only thing of concern, mind you. An unencrypted device, stolen by the wrong hands, isn't just $25 in crack cocaine money...it is much, much more than that in term of lucrative identity theft opportunities. Don't be "that guy". Encrypt your phone. There are walk-through showing how to do that for whatever device you happen to have on YouTube, I am certain.

Bought 2 of these for the wife's & my Android phone. When her's failed after 2 months, we figured it wa just luck of the draw. Now mine failed after just over 4 months, losing a bunch of photo & video (I made sure to back up every few week but even so, we just lost a bunch of photo of our 2 month newborn).Clearly SanDisk had a bad batch with this lot and a the return policy is horrible, I won't be buying any more SanDisk, no matter how cheap (when we bought them on sale around January 2013 they were over half the price of similar SD cards; again, SanDisk clearly knew they had a bad batch, shame on them for dumping them on the customer, no matter how cheap).While I would presumed they would have solved the problem in production, buy at your own risk, SanDisk will sell product with ridiculous failure rate.EDIT: After submitting my review I did some more research on other site and the low star review here. SanDisk is so clearly guilty of selling a defective product from the batch about 6 month ago. Which a I said before, is when they put them on a super discount sale. They knew what they were doing and they are thumbing their nose at customer who just fell outside warrantee (like myself).To knowingly sell your customer something that is going to fail at an unacceptable rate and then ignore them because it failed a little bit outside warrantee is just bad faith. I beg people considering buying this product to not do so, and thumb up the review warning of failures. It is only when company lose sale do they reconsider not screwing their customer like this.Personally I have bought several SanDisk thumb drives, CompactFlash cards, and a Sandisk MP3 player. The thumb drive were ok but I wouldn't buy another mp3 player from them (it wa buggy a hell). Up until now I had an overall neutral to favorable opinion of them, not anymore.If you think I am overreacting, please just skim through a few page submitted in springtime of 2013. There is at least one or more "6 month and it failed" review per page.

I'm a music lover and like to carry my entire music collection around with me everywhere I go. That being said it take up A LOT of space, enough to fill a 64gb memory card on it own (a lot of the file are FLAC format.) I wa a little hesitant to buy the 128gb card when it came out recently because with the 64gb card the first batch were pretty much defective with resulted in a recall. Me, learning of the recall after looking up the issue I wa having had to return the card I bought. SanDisk took the 64gb card back without hesitation and wa actually prepared to do it without the serial number (since I couldn't open my phone at the time because the case is screwed on.)Note to everyone:Quite a few application don't fully support NTFS or newer file system format such a exFAT. To use your SD card without issue you have to format it to FAT32 which IS possible even though it over 32GB. Use the "Fat32Format" tool made by Ridgecrop Consultants, there's a GUI (Graphical User Interface) version available for those unfamiliar with using the command line.------After receiving my new card I formatted it to fat32 since I use a lot of application that aren't the norm and it's easier to use an older file system that is compatible with everything made after 1996. The transfer of file and swapping of card wa seamless, my computer's micro-sd card reader recognized it without trouble a well a my phone. So far everything is good and there's been no hiccups. Even Google Play ha been crashing le when trying to browse my music collection.

The SanDisk Ultra 64 GB is just a storage device, so I don't find that there will be many "features" to get excited about. That being said, it is advertised a having 30MB/s transfer speed, but this is misleading. It can READ up to 30 MB/s, however, and the packaging say this too; it writes at a slower rate. I used this for my phone (too much music) and had the stock 8 GB microSD that came with my phone. I had about 6.5 GB of data that I wanted to transfer back to my new microSD card, and this took about 30 minutes. If this were a strict transfer from my internal hard drive to an external it would be faster, but this is not such a connection. The description on the Amazon page call this a class 10 card with UHS-1 performance. And while technically correct, (Full HD 1080p recording). You would expect more performance in the Sequential Write speeds. It actually doesn't even hit the class 10 speed unless you round up (9.951 MB/s). I have 2 of these card and they both report the same speed. My Kingston 8GB SDHC Class 4 writes at 11.854 MB/s. Now keep in mind the Sandisk beat the other card in the random read and writes. So maybe the design for those faster random read and writes cause the sequential writes to run slower than expected. The default is exFAT, and there seemed to be some comment saying that certain device might not be able to read exFAT.Being the smart alec I am, i decided to format it to NTFS, assuming that my android device will work with it. Tab2 wa not able to read NTFS, and I had to reformat it back to FAT in order to get it work.Subsequently, I tried using those USB-SD card reader (those that look like a tiny usb drive)and realised that apparently the SD card formatting is too new, and it simply will not register a 64GB, but can only read up to 32GB.Have not tried on Note 3 yet, but should work seeing that the technology is pretty on par.

The advertisement call this card a "class 10" card however I wa not able to get "class 10" speed with this card. SD card seem to be MUCH faster at read/write then microSD cards. I get about 10MB/s write speed when copying a file to my SD card through my phone USB cable. I get the same transfer rate when in an adapter. These small memory card seem to be very limited on their write speed. Also, this card did heat up some when transferring to it for a long period of time continuously but not too bad...just warm. The read speed seem to cap out at about 18MB/s but I did see 25MB/s on small files. One thing to note, and this may be by design for this particular card but, this card is super fast when transferring small file but slow at big file so you'll see slower write speed the longer you write to it with larger file whereas smaller file zip along one at a time at that 10MB/s. I wa getting 8.6MB/s when writing a 4.6GB movie file to this card. All in all, this is an excellent card and beyond worth the money for what you get. I love it for my EVO 4G LTE and my previous phone the EVO 4G. The only reason I gave it 4 star is because it did not perform a advertised at 30MB/s. However, if you are thinking of getting this memory card for an Android phone and don't want to pay big bucks, this is your card. Stop reading and buy it, I'm glad I did.

I wa given this card in October to add to my new Samsung Galaxy S3. I wa thrilled I copied a ton of music onto the card and used my phone a my mobile Ipod substitute, leaving my Ipod Classic on my desktop in it speaker system cradle.Everything worked fine until a couple of week ago. I started getting message that seemed to say that I had removed and inserted the memory card. Of course, I hadn't touched it. Then a few day ago the phone told me that the card contained unsupported file and that I needed to reformat it. Well, I tried reformatting. After that, nothing. Nothing at all. I pulled the memory card, reset the phone. Reinserted the card. Nothing. I tried the card in the adapter on 3 computers. It wasn't even visible.I called Sandisk tech support. It didn't take terribly long to convince them that I had a problem. But they quickly offered me two 16 gb card a a replacement. I literally laughed at them. I got the disturbing sense that this is something that they are required to try. If so, that's a lousy business practice. After bouncing me around a few time, they agreed to send me an RMA and a shipping label. I duly sent the card off a couple of day ago. To be frank, I have no idea at all when I might receive a replacement.If I weren't already in the grip of Sandisk, I would buy another card. The fact that 10% of the comment here are negative is an indication of a real quality control problem. A 10% fail rate is simply unacceptable for a product such a this.Update: Well, I do have to give Sandisk credit for customer support. I returned the card using the supplied UPS label on a Tuesday and I received a replacement by UPS on the following Monday. That's very good service. It does, however, increase my suspicion about the offer of two 16 gb because the 32 gb card were "out of stock." If they were out of stock, they sure got "in stock" in a big hurry. In any event, I've upped my rating to two stars.

I wa working with a three of these card using the included adapter, and thought they were slower than they should be. I just bought a full size Sandisk Ultra 16GB class 10 (all the same spec except size theoretically) for a different project, and it writes over twice a fast on the same computer! The write speed on this card is between 7 and 10 MB/s, the read seems to be 35MB/s, compared to the full size card with write speed of 22 to 25MB/s and a read speed of 42MB/s (this is from an imaging program, not a benchmark program, so it's not checking different size of transfer and the like). Compare that with a Transcend 4 GB Class 4 card, the write speed is nearly identical (7 to 9MB/s), while the read speed on the class four is 12 to 13MB/s, significantly slower, a expected.The read speed is good, but the write speed is abysmal! If it say "Class 10", it should be somewhat close to the Class 10 spec.I'm returning them.

I would not recommend this card if your looking for REAL class 10 write speeds. The most I could get is 9mb/s from this card but for the most part it wa about 7-8mb/s. I even did a slow format to exfat in window 7 with no improvements. I copied over music, pic and movie to test it out ranging from a couple of mb to over a gb. The read speed were pretty good at around 21mb/s though. I popped in a 32gb class 10 transcend SD card and it consistently got 16-18mb/s write speed and 24mb/s read speeds. So in conclusion I think this card is not really a class 10. Too bad I read all the negative 1 star review after the fact but I will be sending this one back.

Of late, Sandisk appears to have lost their way a little with their flash storage products. It's almost a universal truth that all of their USB flash drive are hopelessly slow; while they're usually reliable, transfer rate of 4MB/sec or le are worthless when filling a 32GB drive. Fortunately, their "Ultra" line of SD card still appears to buck this trend.Formatted a NTFS and used in anelago Mobile Nano II reader, I see write speed on a 64-bit Linux machine at a consistent 15-16MB/sec when copying large (1GB or larger) file to this card, which more than life up to it class 10 billing. Reads appear to run at about 19-20MB/sec.I can't comment on reliability a I've only had the card a few days, but everything I've copied so far for testing ha made it onto the card (and off again) with no corruption whatsoever; the MD5 checksum of every file I've transferred match the source. That's more than can be said for the Supertalent Pico USB drive that this SD card and reader are intended to replace, which ha never been quite right (it's always occasionally randomly corrupted file of larger than 100MB or so, and the probability of 1GB or greater file surviving wa near zero).32GB appears to be the sweet spot at the moment; smaller card don't cost that much less, and larger card are beyond the SDHC spec and into SDXC territory, which isn't yet universal in term of device compatibility (not to mention they cost far more than double for 64GB).For what I paid for this around Thanksgiving (not part of any explicit sale, but definitely a lower price than appears usual a far a camelcamelcamel is concerned) I'm extremely satisfied.Edit: I should also mention that the included mechanical full-size SD adaptor is one of the worst I've ever encountered. There's a lot of friction when the microSD card is inserted, and it's a right bugger to get it out of the adaptor again. Thankfully I have a few other such adaptor lying around should I ever need one; this one's going in the bin.

I bought two of these 128 gb MicroSD card which I formatted to Fat32, and I currently have about 62 gb in 35,000 file on each card. I carry one card in my wallet and keep one in a safe deposit off-site. I've been through the SanDisk literature looking to see if there are any restriction on their use, other than a ordinary "flash memory" for file storage. There are no restriction I could find. What I have found is that these 128 gb card (and a SanDisk 64 gb card I bought previously) cannot accept 62 gb of data written from a computer without suffering errors. I've had to resort to copying no more than 1/3 gb of data at a time to these cards, stopping, then starting another 1/3 gb until the complete data is copied. The error actually occur early on, at approximately the 2 to 3 gb point. I have several other 128 gb flash memory stick - the Lexar Echo series, a well a a hundred other lower-capacity flash memory cards, and do not have this overflow/error problem with any of those. To repeat, there are no restriction on the use of these memory card (example: can be used only in a camera) given by SanDisk, and given that the 62 gb of data on each card ha been verified a to integrity, they are not defective.

When I bought the u64 back in Feb 2013 (not long after it release) it wa the largest and fastest MicroSD available at the time, and it weighed in at a good price and backed up by SanDisk reputation.For me, and my Galaxy S3 {SCH-i535, currently with Android 4.3} this card ha been a delightful slam dunk on all four counts. I purchased two of these microSDXC card when they were on sale around Black Friday, and have been using them now for just about two months. They work wonderfully and I have had absolutely no problem with either. These SanDisk memory card are 64 GB microSDXC class 10, UHS-1 cards, which are rated for transfer speed up to 30MB/sec.The UHS class 1 designation is intended a an performance measure that indicates the card is capable of supporting real-time full HD video recording. Of course, this only work if you are using a device which is capable of writing to the card at those speeds, but most modern device that offer full HD recording, such a camcorders, digital SLR cameras, and cell phone with built in Full HD recording do support this standard. The benefit of using a UHS-1 card on a UHS certified device is that you should not encounter the problem of buffering or your device stopping recording because it could not write fast enough.However, because these are extra high capacity, sdXC cards, you will need to make sure that your device can support microSDXC cards, and not simply microSD or microSDHC ones. The biggest difference is that the microSDXC standard us the exFAT file system, rather than the FAT32 or NTFS systems. While most modern Android device (and in fact most linux/unix devices) can handle that without difficulty some devices, such a older cameras, Android devices, and some Windows devices, may have difficulty with the format.Having said that, I've been using these in Nikon D80 & D7000 digital SLR cameras, a well a Samsung Galaxy S3 and Galaxy S Relay 4G phone without any difficulty, and they read & write fine on my computers. All in all these were a great buy and I'm very happy with them.

The loss of 2.3 GB(32 to 29.7)explained by the data added when formatting the chip. Seemsto be a legitimate 10 speed. VERY good MicroSDHC! The best!

I bought this card because I have several device that use microSD cards, but not all of them are compatible with the newer and higher-capacity SDXC standard. For SDHC memory cards, 32GB is the largest size available under that technology standard, so I went with this one from Sandisk. That way I didn't have to worry about compatibility issue with any of my devices. I've used Sandisk memory product for a number of year along with many other brands, and I've always had good result from them. I'm happy to say that my experience with this card echo that of 5,000+ other Amazon users; it's been rock steady, reliable with larger file transfer (several 2GB+ movie at a time), and performed a quickly a I'd hoped for a Class 10 card in regard to it read/write times.Aside from the existing review and my previous experience with Sandisk products, I also picked up this particular card due to it UHS-1 compliance. I don't currently have any UHS-1 device that can take advantage of the increased speed, but for the negligible cost difference, it just made sense. Standards and technology update so fast these days; any future-proofing a product can provide to extend it usable life is always appreciated.

(9GB on my super-slow, super-cheap plastic school-kid USB thumb drive take le than 10 minutes.) So then I tested it on various known computer with typical raw and JPG picture files. Read speed ranged from 15-25MB/s, while write speed ranged from 4-8MB/sec for big files, and below 1MB/sec for small files. This is what I would call largely unusable. VERY disappointing.

Although Amazon claim it is a C10 ultra fast Memory Card, it actually ha much slower write speed than other C10 microSD card (it only score about 60% of the normal speed). For example, I have tested it against my old Maxell C10 HC microSD card. The test wa done by writing the same 3035MB random data from DRAM to empty microSD card through a USB3 card reader. The resulting time wa the average value from 3 test of each device:SanDisk Ultra 32GB C10/UHS1: 5m50.816s mean 8.7MB/sMaxell C10 HC: 3m38.787s mean 13.9MB/sThe speed is completely unacceptable for a Class-10 claim (13% lower than 10MB/s, the lowest boundary of Class-10 device), even the over-advertisement of SD card speed are common (claiming 30MB/s for actual 12-15MB/s). It is almost a scam. Some Class-6 card will beat this "Class-10" card.

I guess I should be happy it failed after only 1 month, because I only lost 1 month's worth of picture etc. I bought 3 of these card for my wife, son and I. No a reboot caused my Motorola Defy XT to tell me the card wa blank and needed to be formatted. My laptop won't even recognize the card when I put the card in it's reader. After a couple hour of looking for a way to fix it, I have only found that this is very common for this specific card.EDIT: I wa very happy with Sandisk after calling them. They did say there are compatibility issue with CLASS 10 card and some of the Android phones, and verified my phone is one of them. They offered free replacement with a card that would be certain not to have the same issue mine just had, and also to attempt recovery of my item from the card. These are the reason we buy sandisk in the first place. They did recommend a Class 4 or lower card to me for this phone.I am leaving this a a 1 star, because people should be aware of compatibility issue this severe.2nd Edit: As of March 12, this replacement card, that wasn't going to "be susceptible to the same type of failure" is losing apps etc. I am giving this card up. It ha taken my phone and turned it into a device I cannot count on.

I purchased this Ultra MicroSDHC Class 10 card for my medium player. I wanted to replace my 4GB cardwith this one so I could store more music. I like to have a wide range of music to pick from when I amon vacation or traveling on an airplane long distances. I think I may have bought too much.This card is advertised a water-proof, temperature proof, X-ray proof and shock proof. I will have totake their word for it. I am not going to test it.Just for fun I put the 16GB MicroSDHC disc (30MB/s Read Speed) into it provided adapter and used itin my cheapo cheapo Toshiba Camileo HD movie camera. Even at the Full High Definition resolution of1080p/30fps this disc performed very well. No stuttering, no missed frame and all this under low lightconditions. Nice. Very Nice. Those are big file at Full HD resolution. Read on...This card is 'USH-1' enabled which mean it is the fastest card available (allegedly) and should reachup to a bus interface speed of 104 MB/s; if the electronic device you are using requires it. Of courseif your card reader or device doe not support that speed you will be transferring data at your usualspeed. Sort of like saying it is backward compatible but don't expect blazing speeds. You can feeddata through only so fast.Transferring RAW photo and a Full HD digital film can take a lot of time to transfer. Those are hugefiles to transfer so the USH-I enabled disc is perfect for that purpose. They are working on USH-IIwhich is supposed to allow up to 300MB/s transfers. Talk about instant gratification, we are aboutthere.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Here is a guide by the 'SD Association' with regard to Class rating and video applications:> Class 2 for SD video recording> Class 4 and 6 for high-definition video (HD) to Full HD video recording,> Class 10 for Full HD video recording and consecutive recording of HD stills> UHS Speed Grade 1 for real-time broadcast and large HD video files> UHS Speed Grade 3 for 4K video files-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------USH-I overkill for a medium player? Probably, but for the price it wa a terrific deal to get a Class 10USH-1 enabled card and have the flexibility to use it in a variety of my electronic devices. Hmm. Onsecond thought I may just keep this card for the movie camera and get another "slower" one for mymedia player.As usual I have had no problem with this card. Works well, in or out of the adapter, and seems verytough in it's construction. 5 star for this little power house of a micro card.

With a USB 3.0 card reader, CrystalDiskMark show blazing fast 47MB/s read but disappointingly slow 13MB/s write speed. So you can pretty much forget about reliable 1080P video recording.Update: It is correct that write speed great than 10MB/s is enough for 1080P recording. I need to clarify that the card is very slow when UHS-1 is not enabled. The read/write speed drop to 13.3/7.9 MB/s. For device that are a few year old such a Canon T2i which doe not support UHS, 1080P recording may not be reliable. This card is classified a "class 10," it should support sustained write speed of at least 10MB/s without UHS. It fails my test, a observed by other reviewer a well.

By default it's formatted in exFAT, so don't expect your device will recognize it if they don't support this system. The MS standard allows only 32 GB for FAT32. But who cares? :) There are free tool to format all 64 a FAT32. I personally used Linux and got it done in couple minutes. It wa recognized by Samsung Tablet Note 10.1 right away. I will definitely buy one more for my other devices. One point to the people complaining about the speed. Both your device and adapter should support the speed over 20 MB/S. If you try to use/test this card using USB2, then don't complain. :) You got what you wanted.

( Amazon wa offering a daily deal at the same time period I needed the product) Memory card arrived without delay. Packaging wa very siimple (worry free...for real). Plugged SD card in my slate. PC card slot. Formatted card to exFAT v NTFS ( after more research ).and I wa ready to go. Transferred my photo and music from SSD to the SD card. Freed up valuable SSD real estate for OS use and my Slate PC is again humming with lot more SSD space available. Plays back music, video & photo slideshows smoothly from the card. Delivers on function. Very satisfied with purchase ..and highly recommended 5 star no hesitation !...

A good size and good price for a small camera or phone that take micro SD memory; this is fast but not hyped a AIIIIGH-SUPER-SPEEDY because it doesn't need to be; it's good for all the standard usage of your average consumer (photos, ringtones, games, lightweight video, etc).

I for one have not bought into Google's, or anybody else's, idea that streaming everything is so great. With all the regressive data cap and sketchy throughput, I never want to rely on something being available to me online. Much better to have it local. And with this new card I can finally pack all of my music (~56GB), all of my photos, dozen of reference ebooks, and a few video to boot and still I have around 9GB free a breathing room for my podcatcher. The only real bummer with this card is the speed. Just a I got acclimated to SanDisk's 64GB Extreme Plus level of speed, going back to ordinary class 10 speed that this card ha is a little painful. Luckily playing music or even playing video doesn't oversaturate the read performance. What WILL trip you up however is doing a straightforward copy or move operation while you're listening to something. This card doe not seem to handle multiple simultaneous operation without something going awry. Could not figure out why this card crashed multiple time in my Samsung Galaxy SIII, and demanded a reformatting. Then after 5hrs of call to Sprint & Samsung I got a guy who read factory stuff!Samsung Galaxy SIII is a Class 4 & Class 6 supported Motherboard, with Qualcomm processor. The Sprint store only sell Class 4 memory, and there is a reason that Camera memory~Class 10 is not sold there, the board, just like in a PC, ha to support the data stream. It doe not!If you have an Android Phone you better make sure the motherboard support it! Even Samsung's USA website doe not tell you the board supported memory! I don't want to write a review for each of the 8, 16, 32, and 64 GB SanDisk MicroSDHC Class 10 Cards. They're all 5 stars. They're extremely fast, and a Class 10s, have allowed my Canon SX50's shutter to speed up because it transfer information so quickly with the camera's very small processor. They also allow a burst mode of 9-13 fps which is amazing for a non-DSLR.These card are also very reliable. I've had no read/write failure in the two year that I've been using them.The one "negative" is that they're so small and can be dropped easily when getting them out of the adapter. Still, if you've been working with computer since there wa a gerbil running the power for your PC, you have to marvel at how anything this small can hold more than 30,000 high def 6 GB photo on a 64 GB card that is smaller than your pinky nail.

This is one of the better reviewed SDHC Class 10 card that utilized UHS. By reading the review you will see that it reads/writes at a better speed than many or most card out there right now. Much depends on your phone, how your phone's OS store information on a card and what's inside your device. For MOST of us; you probably will not notice anything different between this card and any other GOOD quality card out there. I usually pick the fastest card on the market when the price drop. The main problem, speed related is when you transfer large amount of data (usually music) onto any card. If you use a standard USB 2 connection this card won't speed that process up. If you use a USB 3 or if you actually put this card into a USB 3 reader to do the transfer; then you'll see a nice boost. If your device requires a card that the product can UTILIZE and ha the OS and chipset to take advantage of this FAST card; it's a no brainer. If your device is older, if you just like storing music; then you can find a cheaper good quality card. If you find this at a good price no matter what you have... BUY IT
