SanDisk Ultra Class 10 micro SDHC card (16GB, 32GB, and 64GB)I purchased the 32GB card for my Samsung Galaxy S3 and the 16GB card for another video recording device. I formatted both card in FAT32 using Windows 7, and functioned without drama in the respective devices. I purchased the 64GB for my GoPro Hero3 Silver edition.The reason I chose the SanDisk Ultra is for the Class 10 speed rating, a well a the waterproof, shockproof, vibration proof, and X-ray proof durability. I had the 32GB Sandisk fail after 2 month of easy usage in my Samsung Galaxy S3. I don't abuse my phone and it is not subject to extreme temperature/vibrations. Sandisk replaced it under warranty but it wa quite a hassle to do this.The 16GB card however, ha been subject to extreme temperature for well over 4 months: from -5F to 100F and that doesn't include solar loading from sitting under the sun, a well a 100% humidity! The 16GB card wa dripping with water after I experienced water intrusion in one of my cameras, and it had been soaked in water (while operating) for several months.The packaging wa easy to open by simply cutting across the top. However, finagling out the blister pack took some patience. The Frustration Free packaging is essentially a cardboard envelope sleeve with a plastic holder and the SD card adapter with microSD card inside. This is how it is shipped!Overall: 4/5 stars. Very affordable and decently fast micro SD cards. These are perfect for smartphones or recording device used in extreme environments. However, one of them failed within 2 months. The speed are also inconsistent. I posted a benchmark photo on Amazon showing my speed with all 3 size of card and the 32GB wa the fastest.UPDATE 28 OCT 2012My 32GB card ha failed after just over 2 month of use in my Samsung Galaxy S3 phone. It started dismounting/remounting intermittently by itself over night. I woke up this morning to find that the card is not readable via the phone and wouldn't work on my PC. The phone ha not been abused and wa not used in an extreme environment. This card wa replaced under warranty by Sandisk.

I bought these microSDXC card for use in my tablet, however, my tablet only recognizes FAT32 formatted card and not the exFAT that these card use. I had suspicion about this based upon other reviewers' experiences. Windows computer will not reformat in FAT32 beyond the 32 GB limit. I wa able to locate a small program that would reformat a drive to FAT32 without the 32GB limitation (FAT32 can accommodate up to a 3 TB drive). I used the Windows GUI version of fat32format (freeware) and it quickly reformatted the memory card. Now the card work in my tablet.

I purchased this card on a daily lighting deal for my new Samsung Galaxy Note II. It wa recognized without issues. I connected it with it adapter to my computer's card reader to transfer about 3Gb of data and the best consistent transfer rate (average) wa roughly 13Mbps... That's le than %50 of the advertised transfer rate.To be fair, I've used the same external card reader with my Sony HX100 digital camera with an SD card (16Gb class 10) and I get double the transfer rate of what I've gotten for this card.Here is the setup:1- SD Adapter included with this card.2- External 12-in-1 USB 2.0 card reader connected to a USB 2.0 port on my PC3- Files transferred were of varying sizes.4- Transferred from 2TB Seagate X2 SATA3 HDD (connected to SATA2 port)5- Windows 8 Enterprise x64 (oh yah baby)The only excuse I give this card for it bad performance is the file were relatively small size but some of them were a large a 50Mb... This still doe not justify the very low transfer rate.I am not really picky because this card will reside inside my super phone but still it doe not justify the money paid for this card.I hope this will help others.

I have read many place that this would not work on Android tablets, but have found that the card requires you to format in a Windows computer to get it to work. Even tablet that are rated to 32GB have been found to read / write this card to 64GB. You need to download a free partitioning program, and format using that to FAT32. First erase the current partition, then repartition to 64GB, then format. You can't simply use Windows to format to FAT32 on newer Windows computers, and even on older Vista, the max it will allow is 32GB at FAT32. Using the partitioning software bypass that 32GB limit and format the whole card so that when you after insert into tablet read something like 59.4GB formatted space. Huge capacity for the money, and a FAST card. Search internet for formatting 64GB microSD card for Android and read up on it.

UPDATE 6/18/14: Well, I suppose nothing last forever. After almost a year, the card ha gone bad. I use the card a lot in my smartphone - a T-Mobile Samsung Galaxy S3 (SGH-T999). All my photos, voice recordings, and downloads go on this card, and the downloads are transferred to my computer almost daily via USB cable. A few day ago, a video file I transferred to my computer refused to play correctly. No video, and the audio wa skipping and squealing, which I recognize a the sound of a corrupted file. I thought maybe the transfer didn't complete; tried it again, same result. I tried to play the file right on the phone, and it didn't play on my phone! I knew there wa a problem. I tried copying the video to my phone storage and playing it there, still no luck. Then I deleted the video and decided to download it directly to my phone, not the SD card - EUREKA. It played perfectly.I formatted the SDXC card twice - once from the phone and once through Windows - and tried the same test. Downloaded video file to the card, then to the phone. Same result both time - it wouldn't play on the SD card, but it did on the phone. All video used to play perfectly on the SD card. Finally, I swapped out the card for my older, Sandisk Ultra 32GB Micro SDXC card. Like magic, it worked perfectly no matter what I played on it. So yeah, the 64GB card is dead. I should note that the card performed flawlessly for nearly a year up until a few day ago.Thankfully, Sandisk Ultra product like this carry an incredible Lifetime warranty - or 10 year for region that don't recognize "lifetime"; their Extreme line of card raise that to 30 years! I've contacted their support for an RMA so I'll update this review a event unfold. If they replace it quickly, I'll bump this back up to 5 stars.ORIGINAL REVIEW:I'm using a Samsung Galaxy S3 smartphone. Sandisk Ultra Micro SD card have never failed me, and this one's no exception. I used to have a 32gb card. They're fast and reliable and never corrupt data, which is more than can be said for some cheaper brand like PNY (those fail quite often). I can't wait to get the new 128GB model!

[[ UPDATE - 6/19/2014 ]]So my lovely wife bought me a Samsung Galaxy Tab 4 for Father's Day and I've been loving it ever since. Just a other with Samsung products, the Galaxy Tab 4 ha the ability to add a microSD card to expand the memory on the device. Since it's been over a year, I decided to do some more research to see if SanDisk offered anything new. As of 6/19/2014, their product lineup for microSD card from worst to best (performance-wise) are the a follows:SanDiskSanDisk UltraSanDisk Ultra PLUSSanDisk ExtremeSanDisk Extreme PLUSSanDisk Extreme PRONow, the difference between all of these card are simply the speed in which you can read/write data to the card. Yes, the published rating of most all these card (except the SanDisk regular) are Class 10/UHS-I but that's just a rating... Actual real world performance doe get better with each model, but with faster card come more expensive prices. Since Amazon doesn't carry the Ultra PLUS model of microSD card, I had to do direct comparison between the SanDisk Ultra ($34.27), Extreme ($57.95), and Extreme PLUS ($67.95).As mentioned in my earlier review, I purchased the SanDisk Ultra for my Galaxy S4. My question was, did I want to pay over $20 more for a card that is faster than the one I already owned? Or I could pay almost double to get SanDisk's 2nd-most fastest microSD card.The Ultra work perfectly fine for my style of usage (storing/capturing picture & HD video and movie playback) on my phone. So in the end, I ended up just buying another SanDisk Ultra 64GB card. I use my cell phone *more* than I do my tablet and if the card is good enough for my phone, it's good enough for my tablet. I don't own a 4K HD camera or anything like that, so I honestly didn't see a need to get one of the faster card at this time.I am now a proud owner of 2 SanDisk Ultra card and have absolutely 0 issue with it in my Samsung devices.[[ ORIGINAL REVIEW - 5/1/2013 ]]I haven't had to buy a microSD card in a long time. The last time I bought one wa for my cell phone over 2 year ago. But since my cellular contract wa up, I knew I would have to get a newer card in addition to my new phone, the Samsung Galaxy S4. Reason for this is because I knew my small 16GB microSD card wasn't going to cut it.Doing research on the Galaxy S4, I wanted to get the best card possible that had decent capacity (32 GB or greater). This led me to find that the Galaxy S4 support the microSDXC Class 10 UHS-I card, which is the fastest possible given that class. Searching for that specifically on Amazon gave me result of only 3 vendor (as of April) that make these microSDXC Class 10 UHS-1 cards. They are Sandisk (the majority), Samsung and Lexar. Nobody else make these that are sold on Amazon.Seeing how SanDisk is a pretty good name out of the 3 (I've used them the most), I decided upon the SanDisk because Lexar wa overpriced and the Samsung one wa overpriced (as well a not eligible for Amazon Prime).But the scary thing is that when you filter by the SanDisk, you literally get DOZENS of options. All of them have different model numbers, different sizes, etc. Then there's that confusion of what's the difference between SDHC & SDXC?SDHC v SDXC:SDHC stand for "Secure Digital High Capacity" and SDXC stand for "Secure Digital eXtended Capacity". Essentially these two card are the same with the exception that SDHC only support capcities up to 32GB and is formated with the FAT32 file system. The SDXC card are formatted with the exFAT file system. If you use an SDXC card in a device, it must support that file system, otherwise it may not be recognizable and/or you have to reformat the card to FAT32.FAT32 v exFAT:The difference between the two file system mean that FAT32 ha a maximum file size of 4GB, limited by that file system. exFAT on the otherhand, support file size up to 2TB (terabytes). The only thing you need to know here really is that it's possible your device doesn't support exFAT. If that's the case, just reformat it to FAT32. REMEMBER FORMATTING ERASES ALL DATA!To clarify the model numbers, I I hopped over to the SanDisk official webpage. What I found there is that they offer two "highspeed" option for SanDisk cards. These are SanDisk Extreme Pro and SanDisk Ultra. SanDisk Extreme Pro is a line that support read speed up to 95MB/sec, however they are SDHC only. To make thing worse, they are currently only available in 16GB & 8GB capacities. Since one of my requirement wa to have a lot of storage, I ruled these out.The remaining device listed on Amazon's search were the SanDisk Ultra line. But here, confusion set in because SanDisk separate these card to two different devices. Cameras & mobile devices. Is there a real difference between the two or is this just a marketing stunt? Unfortunately I'm not sure but I do know the price difference between the two range from a couple cent to a few dollars. Since I wasn't sure, I opted for the one specifically targeted for mobile device (just in case there is some kind of compatibility issue). To find the exact model number, I would go to Sandisk's webpage (sandisk.com) and compare their existing product lineup. From there, you get exact model number and you can then search Amazon for these model numbers. That is how I got mine (SDSDQUA-064G).As for speed tests, I haven't run any specific testing, but copying 8 GB worth of data from my PC to the card literally took just a few minutes.One last note is that Amazon attache additional character to the end (for example SDSDQUA-064G-AFFP-A v SDSDQUA-064G-U46A). The difference between the two is that the "AFFP-A" mean "Amazon Frustration Free Packaging". Other than that, these are exactly the same. If you're wondering what I got (and want to use it in your Galaxy S4), I got the SDSDQUA-064G-u46A and it work like charm.

No question, it is really a fast a it's rated. How fast? Well, class "10 SDHC" mean literally SD format, HC=High Capacity, Class 10 = 10MB/sec read-write. How fast is 10MB per second? Well, Class 4, the most common step down (i.e. cheaper) is Class 4, i.e. 4MB/sec. So Class 10 is 2.5 time faster. Why pay the difference?Digital cameras: at some point the number of pictures/sec or HD video is bottle-necked by the speed of the medium it is being recorded to.Smart phones? I have a Samsung Note II. A Quad-core processor, wiz-bang yadda-yadda. Yes, I DO notice speed difference in camera, app performance (I use a spreadsheet app/browser/NetFlix/Music streaming, et al) is noticeably FASTER. Where do you think the phone store stuff to when it doesn't use the factory installed memory? (iPhomes don't have an SD slot, and I wouldn't own a phone or tablet that doesn't -- I believe in choice in the computer realm)Oh yeah, SanDisk is a leader and pioneer in the SD format (where do you think the 'SD' came from?). The only other SDHC Class 10 card worthy of comparison is the Samsung brand, but then I might be biased on that one.

I bought this extra memory for my Samsung Galaxy S4. I wish I had known when I bought my phone that Android changed it memory management technique between Gingerbread and Jelly Bean! Verizon sold me a 16GB Samsung S4. I didn't do much research since my old phone broke and I wa about to leave on a business trip the next day. Come to find out, there are 32 and 64GB version of the Galaxy S4! I never asked Verizon if they even carried different versions. Well, I figured that wouldn't be a problem... I'll just put in a 64GB Micro SD (TF) Card and I'll be all set. Unfortunately you can no longer transfer Apps to the Micro SD Card. Some apps can store data on the SD Card but there is no longer the ability to "Move to SD." Since I travel internationally, I use a lot of GPS mapping software and would like to download multiple Gigs of map data for offline mapping. As of now, I can only download this to my phone's 16GB memory, and not to this 64GB memory card! Pictures (except for burst photos), video and music can all be put on the 64GB SD card. All that being said, this memory card work well, and is priced on par with all of the other comparable card on the market. If you've got the cash and need the space (for music, videos/movies and/or pictures--just not apps) then I recommend picking one of these up.

I had bought this card for my new Samsung Galaxy S3. The card is about a good a you can expect for the price and technology you're paying for.SDXC card come formatted in exFAT by default, which is what I would have tried to format it a anyway and seen if my phone support that filesystem. In addition to being a faster format, enabling higher transfer rates, exFAT also take up le storage space than, say, an FAT or FAT32 filesystem would - which is important when considering mobile storage devices.I read several poor review about this product starting that it simply stopped working after a few months. While that can happen from regular use, a it ha happened to me in the past with a couple 32GB SDHCs, I would venture to say it wa an error in use. Flash medium is very sensitive in regard to "hard shutdowns". that's to say, just pulling it out of your device or card reader without first unmounting it. Within the 'Data Storage' menu on Android phones, there is an option to 'unmount SD card'. I would recommend that you ALWAYS select this before removing any external memory card to avoid corruption of data and, ultimately, the card itself. The reason for this is that sudden stoppage of a flash memory device's data or power connectivity can easily result in corruption.Transversely, if you have the memory card plugged into a card reader, say, with an SD adapter; you should first "Eject" the card. In Windows, there is a small icon located in the taskbar notification menu for "Safely Remov[ing] Hardware and Eject[ing] Media". Select the card and a notification will pop-up that the card is now safe to remove. It basically severs the same function a the Android 'unmount' optional but will also cease any current read/write operation to avoid data or device corruption.I cannot speak for how one would do this on a Mac OS but chance are, if you're using an Apple PC, you don't have an Android phone.

I'm sure it would be fine in any other scenario though, but it's advertised a a class 10/UHS 1 card and it's just not a fast a other class 10/UHS 1 cards.Drift Innovation (the company that make the Ghost-S camera I use) ha stated in multiple support ticket with me not to use any "SanDisk Ultra cards" because they do not perform fast enough for the camera and will result in slow card errors. They work ok until you try recording 1080p video at higher frame rates.

What else can I say... this SanDisk 32 GB class 10 work like a charm in my Galaxy SII i9100 (unlocked). If you're upgrading from an old smaller microSD card, I did this:1. Create a .img file of the old microSD with HDD Raw Copy Tool (freeware)2. Recover the saved .img file in the new microSD card with HDD Raw Copy Tool* Since the old microSD had only 8 GB, the new microSD card will have only 8 GB D:3. Install Minitool Partition wizard (freeware) and choose the new microSD.4. Choose the Move/Resize option.5. Drag the space to the full size of the new microSD card6. Don't forget to Apply7. Put the microSD in your phone and there you go all your stuff and apps saved to the microSD working.

I had been using a 'regular' SanDisk 32GB Micro SD card that came included with my HTC Thunderbolt I bought in 2011. The size wa decent, but I never realized until upgrading how much I wa lacking on the speed.I finally got one of these to replace my old card with my Galaxy S3. It is superb. I just recently got a Galaxy S4, and again, this card is just about the best expansion you can add to most any phone.With my old MicroSD card, I had gotten used to just sitting there, zoning out, a I waited patiently for my computer to transfer pictures/videos off my card to be backed-up to my PC's hard drive, or copying some music file from my PC to my card. With this new card, almost any single file (even hundred of megabyte big) is an instant transfer, that transfer too quick to even bring up that "moving" dialog box in Windows 8. On my very big transfer (lots of HD video file at once, totaling several gigabytes), I have to wait, but I'm waiting for second instead of minutes.Combine the excellent speed with the fact that 64GB can hold a ton of data (compared to typical storage size on phones), and you have a very satisfied customer. Now I can procrastinate even longer the occasional transfer of all my picture and video to my PC, though I try not to.A lot of phone (like my S4) specify 64GB SDXC card a the maximum they support, so this is about the best you can even get for the moment, unless you want to pay almost double for SanDisk's Extreme cards. Unless you have money to burn, I think these are a much better value and diminishing return certainly kick in beyond this price point. But perhaps my next phone will support 4K HD video onto 256GB card and I will yet again need to upgrade my card's capacity and speed... Anyway, bottom line on this product: AWESOME.

Music only take about 5 second after starting the car to start playing, skipping, fast forwarding or searching all work flawlessly. Ok, this is how I transferred the file on my old microSD card to this one.1. Turn off device and remove old microSD card2. Put old microSD card in adapter and put into laptop (SD card can be found in "My Computer:).3. Copy all the file and paste onto laptop in "My documents"4. Remove old microSD card and insert new microSD card into laptop.5.Copy file in "My documents" and paste them directly to new microSD.6. Put new microSD in the device and turn device on. Enjoy the space!-Quick note: The actual space on this card is roughly 29.7 GB due to some formatting and file already on the card. Hope this helps.

Works well. Came with an SD adapter and I'm using it in a portable video camera. Captures everything, even 1080p at 30 fps just fine. No rate issues.

I tested it in several UHS-1 compliant device and found the write speed at 11-12 MByte/Second. Sounds fine for a class 10 card but this is not what I wa paying for. I don't expect it to run anywhere close to UHS-1 interface speed (104 MB/S) but it should be close to 30 MB/S a the manufacturer advertised. I have a lot more choice if I am only looking for a class 10 card.Indeed, microSD card are usually slower than full-size SD card. They use the same Flash controller so the reason is really microSD card use slower NAND Flash. Manufacturers know you are not going to use microSD card in high-speed SLRs so they get to sell you lower quality NAND at a premium. My advice to you the photography enthusiast is to buy full-size SD card rather than microSD card with adaptors.That said, the compatibility is great. It work great with my tablets, PCs, GPSs and phones. That is what I like about SanDisk. They do thorough compatibility test before product release.

I bought the 64GB Ultra card to increase storage on my Acer A500 Android Ice Cream Sandwich 4.0.3 tablet. It didn't work a Android doesn't support it native exFAT formatting from the factory. Insert the card into an SD adapter and plug it into a PC or Laptop under real Windows. Reformat this card to the NTFS format with Windows Format utility and Android can then read and write any size file, even file over 5GB, to and from this card. You do NOT need to root or modify the Android tablet in any way, except to have ver 4.0.3 operating system on it. This product is very fast reading and writing and ha proven very reliable...a great value in some really serious storage space.

I purchased the card in the Sandisk packaging, so I am pretty sure it is genuine. I tested it with various program on the web that apparently can detect whether they are fake or not. This one turned out to be a real Sandisk card. The card came formatted with FAT32.I read on the web about these micro SDs, and apparently they are not a fast a the full SD card version. I borrowed my brother Sandisk 32gb full SD card to make comparison tests. Here are my official/unofficial test result using DiskBench V2.6.2.0 and H2testw 1.4 test. I will give the result a an "overall" result, because after testing these card over and over with speed writes and reads, the result get mixed and varied to a big degree... much larger than I expected, but the numerous test showed me a "general" trend. The trend is that the full SD card do write faster than the MicroSD card. But, also remember that the microSD had to be put into an adapter to do the test on my PC while the fullSD card wa put into the computer reader directly.These are just my averages, but:Small file writes:Both SD card wrote at close to 10mb/sec. The microSD wa le consistent in the test and sometimes dropped to 8mb/sec.Small file reads:Both SD card read at close to 20 mb/sec at their fastest.Large file copy to card:MicroSD wrote at 3.5mb/sec while the fullSD wrote at about 4mb/secLarge file read copy from card:MicroSD wa 10mb/sec while the fullSD read at about 14mb/sec.My conclusion:My test were by no mean official for this card and showed much variance dependent on file size of the read and writes, but the fullSD card wa faster in many cases, but equal to microSD in most cases. The small file writes and read showed that they are similar enough. But, my only concern is with large file writes.... is 3.5 mb/sec good enough for rapid photography on a high pixel camera? I don't know. I have had no problem using these card with H264 movie capture for hours. I am surprised that 3.5 mb/sec is enough.Also, never during the huge file copy to the card did I get any noticeable heating of the card itself, by touch even for an hour. I've noticed that it ha been a complaint from many people on the web, some stating that they felt they might burn themselves. I copied file that took more than an hour with no noticeable temperature change, other than, perhaps a couple of degrees. Of course, this wa on a PC and not installed in a camera.The card performs well for video work, and appears to meet many other test performed by other people. I never saw a read close to 30 mb/sec... they were very consistent at 20 mb/sec at the highest performance.I would get the card again, if the price were right.

The Nexus One is listed a supporting a maximum of 32GB on an SDCard.Based on report here and elsewhere, I took out my 32GB card and put in this 64GB card and powered up the phone.The phone reported that the card wa defective in a notification.I pulled down the notification and tapped the notification that issued that report. It offered to format the card.I would note that I have Clockwork Recovery and the ROM Manager app installed on my rooted (CM7, Android 2.3) N1.After tapping the notification, the phone formatted the card. All went well. Since I had neglected to move my RootExplorer file manager off the SD card prior to putting in the new card, I wa not able to check directly on the phonethat the entire 64GB wa available. But, a it turned out, it was.While doing the above, I had been using Winzip to make a copy of the content of my 32GB card to my PC (using a USB adapter). When that completed,I powered down the phone and put the new 64GB card in the PC using the Micro SD adapter that came with that card and a USB adapter for that adapter.It showed about 60GB (the usual for a 64GB card, I guess).Interestingly, some file (mainly folders) related to clockworkmod had been placed on the SD card during formatting, which show where the formatting codeprobably came from. Take note: if you do *not* have ROM Manager / Clockworkmod on your phone, your mileage may very well vary. If you have root, I would suggest obtainingROM Manager from Google Play prior to doing the above. Anyway, I just deleted those file so that they wouldn't conflict with any of the old file I wa aboutto copy.I then unzipped the saved content of my old card onto the new card.Then, I put the new card in the N1 and powered it up. It worked perfectly, right away.Root Explorer showed about 60GB of capacity (of which about 30 wa used by me - I really needed this card!).Tried out Spotify Premium and it played fine from saved file that had been on the old card and were now transferred to the new card. Other thanRoot Explorer, haven't tried any other apps yet, but am expecting good news based on the experience thus far!I tried a full backup using ROM Manager and it apparently worked without incident.So, based on the above, I would recommend this card for the Nexus One! What a break to get another 30 GB on an aging phonethat is nonetheless still one of the best phone ever.Caveat: Keep in mind that I just unwrapped this thing and have used it for all of two hours.

I bought this card, originally for my Galaxy Note II, with the intention of using it a my primary downloader, but I could not get it to format correctly for the phone, even using third party format software.I then tried it in my Galaxy Tab2 7.0plus......same problems.I finally, and ridiculously, put the card in my Nikon D5100 camera. I could take a whopping 8k photos, on high/large setting (not that I would ever need to take that many photo in one session). This wa the last option I had, to use the card.It worked well, taking photo of a holiday, and thankfully, it did not fail before I could get my photo onto a computer. Since then, I have inserted it back in the camera, and reformatted (like you always should), and bam, one photo is good, after that, failure, every single time. So now I have a 64GB card, that is capable of taking and storing ONE PHOTO at a time, before I must run a "fix file system" on my computer.Don't waste your money on this card, over priced, not really faster than the other card I have, and zero longevity. This may be a one off, but I think it is a problem created by the proprietary format exFAT, that make this card a loser, or more to the point, the poor customer who buy it.UPDATE JULY 2012After contacting sandisk, they have offered an RMA, but first they must verify that I have not tried to "recover" or "wipe" the data on the card, and I must ship it, at my expense, to Taiwan. I have since emailed them in reply to the requested information (date of purchase, photo of the card, packaging ect), and I told them that the data on their is my data, and if I could have accessed the card, I would have wiped it, why should I give them my information, stored on the card? That make me le than happy, I am guessing that they want to discourage returns. Who would want to send data to a company, not knowing who will access it, and what they will do with the information contained? I would have wiped the card, but it wa unreadable, unable to format, unable to do anything. I will send it to them, hoping that the information is destroyed, along with the bad card.Sandisk, you are asking a whole lot of your customers, and since this card ha gone bad, I have had several other card from them, go bad a well, seems to be a whole lot of card being shipped that die in very short time periods. I used to love their products, and their older flash drive are great, still using a micro cruzer that is 6 year old, and going strong. I have not had one single microSD card, from this company, last more than three months, since I moved to the Philippines. Either they send their junk to the Philippines, or they have dropped QC from their business model, to create higher profit margins.**UPDATE 2**After emailing Sandisk, and expressing my displeasure with having to return the item, intact, so that they can "assess" the card, and look at/recover what ever personal information may have been stored on the card, they rescinded. I can only assume that they want to get the card back, to verify that it is bad, or make sure that you are not just trying to get a free card out of them, which I can understand. Instead of requiring me to send the card back to them, they asked that I cut the card, and send a photo of the "destroyed" card, so they could process a new card, to be sent to me, directly in the Philippines. I hammered them pretty hard in this review, and in the email I sent to them, regarding the bad card, and sometimes, you get results, in this case, I give them 5 star for doing the right thing. I had no problem cutting the card, since it would not operate in any of my device anyway, but I did have a problem returning the device, intact, with out knowing what information wa stored on the card (banking, amazon account info, passwords, ect.) I would have just kept the card, destroyed it, and never bought another from sandisk. With their faith restoring gesture, I will not remove them from my list of company to avoid. I just hope that they get better at QC. I returned another defective card to the retailer yesterday, only to find out that you MUST have the original packaging for a replacement. I wa lucky to still have one of my packages, but since I bought several of the cards, I am not sure if I gave them the matching package for the card I returned.I would suggest that if you are like me, and have several device (2 DSLR's, galaxy Tab2, galaxy Note 2, SII, LG-P920), that you find a way to mark each card/package, and keep the package, in the case that the card should go bad. I have had more than half of my sandisk 32gb cards, fail on me, in le than 6 months. I only buy them, because of the card available in my area, these are the best, which is scary, with such a high failure rate.

SanDisk make a lot of claim about this card and some of them are questionable. I own two, and while the high-capacity/low-price certainly make them useful, they're not the answer to all of my recording needs. First of all, do not use this with a GoPro Hero 3 (or later model). Despite SanDisk's claims, these card cannot handle the demand of true HD recording. GoPro removed it from their list of recommended card because it caused the camera to lock up and turn off. Even with myCanon VIXIA HF10 Flash Memory High Definition Camcorder--technology which is over 10 year old--the SanDisk Ultra card doe not meet the requirement for shooting in FXP mode (1920x1080, 17Mbps) even though the camera say only a class 4 is required. A firmware update to the GoPro 'fixed' the issue for Hero 3 and Hero 3+ cameras, but it did so by throttling the recording speed for the cards, i.e. lowering the quality of the recording slightly.Those shortcoming aside, the SanDisk Ultra can shoot in XP+ mode (1440 x 1080) on the Vixia HF10 and it work with all of the setting of aContourROAM Waterproof HD 1080P. Is it "water-proof, temperature proof, X-ray proof, shock proof"? I can't say. The ContourROAM is a waterproof camera, so even non-waterproof card are safe for submersion if they're in the housing. The Ultra ha functioned in 10 weather and after being dropped, so there's validity to the claim of it being temperature- and shock-proof. I guess I'll find out whether it's x-ray-proof the next time I go through the airport...

I got my wife a Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 10.1 for Christmas, and it took awhile for her to start figuring out all the thing it can do. Once she did, that led, of course, to her wanting to watch movie on it. That wa my signal to spring into action, that is, if I wanted to prevent her from running wild, buying "digital copies" of every movie we already have in DVD or Blu-Ray. You can't play DVD or Blu-Ray movie on this device, but you CAN use your computer's DVD or Blu-Ray drive and commonplace third-party software to convert movie in this format into ".mp4" and/or several other type of video file that CAN be played on this tablet.Since this particular tablet is capable of playing high-definition video (screen resolution is 1280 x 800 pixels), and we want to use ALL of that high-def capability, my conversion file tend to be pretty large (average 5 to 10GB per movie) ... way too big to be stored on the tablet's limited internal memory. That's where the tablet's microSD slot ... and this SanDisk flash memory ... come in. I make HUGE mp4's, store them separately on a 1.5 terabyte drive, and then load a many of them a I can on this chip, which show up in the tablet a a separate memory source. Then all you have to do is pull up one of the movie file from the card, and hit play. You can use the device's standard video player, or get an app with more controls.Watching high-def video on a tablet that's streaming the data from a memory card (rather than the tablet's internal memory) requires a memory card with very high "read speed," and this SanDisk card's "Class 10" rating fill that bill. That's the difference between cheaper microSD that's primarily designed for simple data storage, and microSD that's designed for higher active transfer/read speeds. The "Class 10" designation generally mean that the subject card will transfer data at a MINIMUM rate of 10MB per second. This SanDisk "Ultra" card is capable of transferring data at speed of up to 30MB per second, depending on the speed of the device you're using it in, and other particular of the way you're using the device."Frustration free packaging" mean the chip, SD adapter, and plastic case come in a little, sealed cardboard envelope with a pull tab opener. This card come pre-formatted for Android, and my use of it in the Galaxy Tab 3 for watching high-def .mp4 movie ha thus far been flawless.Finally, don't let yourself get burned by counterfeiter in trying to save a buck. While pricing on memory tends to fluctuate, Amazon's current pricing on this card is VERY competitive with any/all vendor out there selling GENUINE SanDisk "Ultra" memory. Buy from Amazon, or other trustworthy vendor, because I just learned the hard way that these memory card are being counterfeited in huge number ... that is, the counterfeiter are placing SanDisk labeling/packaging on inferior, generic microSD, and selling the bogus chip on Ebay and anywhere else they can. I bought THREE from Amazon after I got burned by a Chinese seller on Ebay. The counterfeit packaging and labeling wa good enough to fool me, until I actually tried one of the chip in the Galaxy Tab 3 ... the write speed (that is, the amount of time it take to transfer file ONTO the microSD card) wa dramatically worse than the speed of a genuine SanDisk "Ultra" card, and the read speed wa totally inadequate for playing movie on the Galaxy Tab 3. I may never have figured it out at all if I didn't already have one other, genuine SanDisk "Ultra" with which to compare the fakes.If you want the best, most reliable memory for the microSD slot on your shiny, new Android device, look no further ... this is it.

If you look through the review you will see that this card seems to have both a failure rate and a incompatibility with some devices. I bought this card in November of 2012 and it worked great for a while. The card started failing in my Galaxy Note 2 in the beginning of January. After reformatting and trying the card in other device it still doe not work. Please understand that this is not a user error but appear to be something wrong with the card itself. I have tried the card in 3 different phones. 1 with stock Jelly Bean, 1 with Ice Cream Sandwich, and 1 with a Cyanogenmod custom firmware. All 3 device have problem and say "blank sd card" or "unsupported filesystem". Even formatting the card in both Windows and using Android do not seem to fix the issue. I wa happy to find such a good price on a large microsd card but sadly it look like you get what you pay for. It doe appear that some people are having luck so it might be worth a gamble of $20 if you are feeling lucky. If you do buy this card it would be wise to double check your backup process to make sure you do not lose picture or video if you have this problem. I am glad I used dropbox for my phone so I did not lose any picture or videos.

I bought two of these at different times. Both of them had the retail packaging with the Android on them and the model number matched the packaging.The first one wa 32GB. I tested this out with dd on my built-in SD card reader on my MBP and on a GFR204SD USB device and couldn't get more than 8 MB/s average write speed. Would bounce up and down between 6 and 10. The Class speed is supposed to be the minimum, not the maximum. R/W off the HDD wa above 20, so that wasn't the bottleneck. Neither is UHS compliant, but I should at least be able to get the Class 10 rating out of this. Read @ 30 MB/s is pretty accurate.The second one (64GB) I tested by just watching Activity monitor to see if it wa in the ballpark. Bounced between 8 and 10 copying from a hard drive or a RAM disk. Sounds like probably Class 10. Read speed to RAM disk wa about 24 MB/s.

Recently I bought a Microsoft Surface RT tablet and used the 32GB version of this memory card. Worked great and I didn't have any problems. So, when I heard that the Surface RT could be expanded to 64GB, I immediately looked for a great deal online. Behold... Amazon offered this card for under $50 AND it wa Prime eligible! Woo-Hoo! To me, it wa a "no-brainer" and I quickly ordered this inexpensive upgrade. Like it predecessor, it come with the memory card, an SD card adapter, and a small plastic case. installing the card is super easy on the Surface, because you just line it up with the slot and push it in till it clicks! That's it! No formatting required and the card run quite fast! Normally, I buy SanDisk Extreme memory card (which are faster), but this particular card had no problem running video file or playing music.Anyway, if you get this card for your Surface RT tablet, DON'T format it! Why? Well, the card is already formatted, so why risk messing up your card? Just pop it in and enjoy greater space on your Surface!Note: As far a I know, you cannot install Surface apps onto the memory card, only medium file and documents. Still, this card is a great upgrade and I highly recommend it!

I have tested this card in both a Samsung Galaxy Note 3 phone and aSamsung Galaxy Tab 3 (10.1-Inchand it wa immediately recognized by both devices. As I write this review the card ha been running in my Tab 3 and constantly used for over a week.Other review have dissected the spec of this card, so I'll share how I use it and why I prefer these over the 64GB card (which I also own and use). The price point on these 32GB card have dramatically fallen and a of the date of this review they are priced a commodities. I use a few pair of these to rotate backup on my laptop, so I always have a daily snapshot of my documents. For that purpose alone these card are well worth it.For my tablet I have divided my extensive music library into genre and have them backed up to these cards. A 32GB card will hold about 150 CDs, so the space saving along over the physical medium is significant. In fact one of these card cost about the same a a rack for 150 CDs.These are also excellent for saving practice session that I sometimes record using my phone or tablet. I pop my primary SD card out of the device and swap one of these in to video record. Since this card will hold about six hour of video it's perfect for that use.Overall, these are reliable card that have worked in a number of device I own. I can assure anyone wanting to use them in a newer Samsung Note 2 or 3 phone or Tab 3 tablet that this card will work, and it is also excellent for HD video recording. At the price point it's an absolute bargain.

I purchased this card for use in a Microsoft Surface Pro tablet -- for that, it work great. 64GB is a nice capacity, card wa cheap and it work just fine.The problem, however, wa in transfer speed. It's rated at "up to" 30MB/sec which I guess is true.. but mine ha never reached anywhere close to that. Using 3 different reader (the Surface Pro itself, a higher-end desktop PC with built-in MicroSD reader and an external USB 3.0 MicroSD reader.. in all, it maxed out around 10-12MB/sec (and on multiple smaller file it maxed out closer to about 5MB/sec total). I know it's not the card reader a I have been able to reach speed of 90MB/sec with other/faster cards.The card itself DOES work fine. For that I give it 5 stars. The price is great for the size, for that I give it 5 stars. The transfer speed are just disappointing though.. taking 5 minute to transfer an iTunes movie file is a long time.. it'll take hour to fill the full card.. If you only load data once, it's not so bad, but if you're always adding/deleting/moving data, it's slow and will get annoying quickly!

My review is a little backwards… but I thought the most relevant should go first.WARNING: ONLY BUY THIS CARD ON SALE!The *typical* price since summer 2013 is about $24 for 32 GB, and about $48 for 64 GB. DO NOT pay any more than this, and you can actually pay le if you have the luxury of time / patience.The lowest (non-lightning) price hit about $18.00 for 32GB and $35 for 64GB, in early December. I basically buy when the price hit $20 or less, and the 64 nears $40.00.From December 2013 to January 2014, I watched these card change price on an almost daily basis. They initially went on sale for about $17.95 and $34.95 for 32 and 64 respectively. I watched them slowly increase in price, with random dip and peak for a month. On January 6th 2014, they still show a a "Best Deal on Amazon" for "7 more days" but they are at the highest price point since last summer -- and higher than I have *ever* payed for these cards! So don't let the "Best Deals" section deceive you, at $27/$50, these are NOT a "deal" in term of price.Okay, here's my actual "review" of these absolutely great SDXC cards.****I have tried a variety of MicroSDXC cards, and so far the Samsung Ultra UHS1 are the best -- and the price can't be beat -- for all the most important reasons: speed, capacity, reliability, durability.I have not had a single failure, and I use these card in my Nook HD+, Nexus 7 2013 (via USB) and my Canon 5D Mark II (with converter) and MacBook Pro (In the card slot). They're durable and waterproof, and I can use the same card in all these device without reformatting. I even had one go through the wash, and I still use it for pictures.For the technically inclined, I have card with *both* the Clockwork Mod bootloader (for the Nook HD+) and the MagicLantern firmware for my Canon EOS 5D II on the same card. I can pull it from the Nook, shoot picture with the camera, and look at the result on the Nook by just pulling the card out of one device and placing it in the other. This should be possible with any SDXC/SDHC card, but it turn out that the Samsung UHS1 is the only card I've found that work reliably. Some card won't boot because they're too slow too finicky, but all my Samsung UHS1s work great (the 64GB will not boot in the Nook, but no 64GB card will).I keep my eye open for price drop on these card because they've performed so well for me. Samsung also ha a newer, faster card, but it price-point hovers somewhere north of "prohibitive" so I still stick with these. And that's good news regardless because a the new card increase it market share, these should drop even further in price.

I bought two of the 32 GB Sandisk Ultra microSDHC cards, and both of them were unusable.The first one stopped accepting new data when I had put a bit le than one gig of data onto the card. I couldn't add more files, and I couldn't reformat the card. If I tried to write a new file onto the card, the write operation seemed a if it worked, but the new data couldn't be read back successfully. The file already on the card were still readable, though, so basically, the card had become a 1 GB ROM. Fortunately, there wa no sensitive personal information on the card, so I returned it to Amazon.The second one didn't fail the same way, but it wa still unusable. If I transferred a bunch of file and then read them back, most of the transferred file had data errors. For example, a 3 minute music file might only be able to have it's first minute of music played back, then the bad data would stop the music player. I ran a write/readback test and confirmed that there were data error on nearly every block tested. (I used Flash_Drive_Tester_v114.exe, which is a free download.)I ended up buying the equivalent Transcend productTranscend Information TS32GUSDC10 32GB micro SDHC10 Flash Memory - No Box or Adapterwhich ha been performing flawlessly. I have over half of the capacity in use, and I've never seen any sign of data loss or corruption. For USB plug in flash drives, I've had good luck with SanDisk products, but my experience with the SanDisk microSDHC card ha been terrible.

I have tested dozen of SDHC and micro-SDHC cards. One disturbing trend I noticed is that: the speed class rating for micro-SDHC is typically inflated. For example, a 'class-10' rating mean the card must deliver a sequential write speed of at least 10MB/s. But somehow, a class-10 microSDHC card is always slower than a class-10 SDHC card from the same manufacturer. Case in point: thePNY 32 GB microSDHC Card (P-SDU32G10-EFS2)claims to be 'class-10', yet it can only write at 8.6MB/s maximum, while the full-sizePNY P-SDHC16G10achieved 13.4MB/s according to CrystalDiskMark v3.01.ThisSanDisk Ultra 32 GB microSDHC Class 10 UHS-1 card (SDSDQUA-032G-U46A), however, prof to be the exception. It achieved a sequential write speed of over 10MB/s according to two different benchmark program (11.8MB/s in "CrystalDiskMark", 10.6MB/s in "H2testw v1.4"). This is faster than all my other microSDHC cards, including two 'class-10' card fromPNYandPolaroid.A closer look at the file transfer speed using "Flash Memory Toolkit" revealed another nice surprise: For writing small files, this Sandisk Ultra microSDHC card performed just a well a it full-size counterpart, theSanDisk Ultra SDHC (SDSDU-032G-AFFP). In contrast, all my other class-10 microSDHC card perform poorly while writing smaller files. See the benchmark result I uploaded to 'Customer Images' for details.When you use a memory card in a digital camera to record HD video, it need to store a huge video file each session. That mean it sequential write speed is most critical. When used in a tablet or a smart phone, however, the card's random write speed for small file is more important. That's why in such applications, the Sandisk microSDHC will perform faster than the PNY and Polaroid cards, even though they are also rated a 'class-10'.[Bottom Line]As of this writing, the Sandisk Ultra microSDHC card ia actually priced lower than other class-10 card from PNY and Polaroid. This make the Sandisk the best value - especially if you need honest class-10 performance across all platforms.[Side Notes]- Do not confuse this Sandisk Ultra card withSanDisk Mobile Ultra microSDHC (SDSDQY-032G-U46A). The latter is rated for class-6 only.- The size of this '32GB' card is 29.7GB according to my computer. This is actually normal because computer people count one Gig a "2 to the power 30", which is 7.3% larger than one billion. So 29.7GB translates to 31.9 billion bytes, which is '32GB' according to marketing people.[Update on Feb 4, 2013]1. Amazon combined the Sandisk Ultra 32GB and 64GB card on the same product page. Please beware that your intended appliance must be compatible with 'SDXC' in order to used the 64GB version. My original review refers to the 32GB 'SDHC' version.2. There are two part number for the same card. If you start from the Amazon product page and select 'Retail Packaging', you'll see the part number of SDSDQUA-032G-U46A. But if you click on 'Frustration Free Package', the part number change to SDSDQU-032G-AFFP-A.[Update on Oct 5, 2013]The Sandisk microSDHC card work great in my new Samsung Galaxy S3, without the need for reformat (the default format is FAT32)[Update on Dec 26, 2013]My old test result were limited by the card reader and USB 2.0 port used. I re-tested the Sandisk UHS1 micro card using theTranscend RDF5 Card Readerconnected to an USB 3.0 port. Here are the result from 'CrystalDiskMark 3.01 x64':- Sequential Read speed = 40.0MB/s (was 34.8MB/s when connected to USB 2.0 port)- Sequential Write speed = 13.1MB/s (was 12.6MB/s when connected to USB 2.0 port)

It appears that the 32GB SanDisk Ultra Micro SD Card I purchased from Amazon wa defective. I installed it in my Samsung Tablet, but could not successfully transfer file using either a USB cable or WiFi. The file transfer would appear to start, but then would slow down and hang completely. It did this on every one of multiple attempts, with different file types, and number of file ranging from many to just a single file. I tried loading file onto the card directly from my PC, but then the Tablet would not see them. I tried reformatting the card both in my PC and in the Tablet, but still got the same result. After a few tries, the Tablet would appear to format the card but then tell me that the card wa blank/unformatted. I did an A/B/A with an old 8GB Sandisk Micro SD Card that I had laying around. It worked perfectly -- formating, transferring files, reading and writing file -- everthing worked. I put the 32GB SanDisk Ultra Card back in the Tablet, but had the same problem again. I concluded that the SanDisk Ultra card wa defective and returned it. I'm still using the old 8GB card without a hiccup.The good thing wa that Amazon's return policy wa quick and painless.

The primary reason for buying this extra capacitySanDisk Ultra 64 GB microSDXC Class 10card wa to use it inSamsung Galaxy Tab 2 (10.1-Inch Model GT-P5113)and I am happy to share that you can get this to work flawlessly after some initial glitches. (Read below)Firstly you need to be aware that the Samsung Tablet Model GT-P5113 currently run with Android OS 4.1.1 with Kernel 3.0.31-523998 and Build number JRO03C.P5113UECLK7.(Jelly Bean) My experience shared here are with that level of Android OS your experience may vary depending on what version of OS you are running. The SanDisk Ultra 64 GB microSDXC card purchased from Amazon (Retail Packaging) get recognized just fine however when the tablet's Media Device A.K.A 'MTP' application attempt to talk your PC via USB cable the Tablet simply reboots! and after that the card is presented to the PC. - Really strange indeed!This baffled me for couple of hours. Firstly, I attempted to format the card (exFAT) in PC and it formatted just fine. After that I attempted to use it in the tablet to see the same behavioral oddity of instantaneous reboot of the tablet a 'MTP' application try to communicate with the PC. This made me investigate the issue further and I determined the root cause wa the fact that SANDISK now seen to factory format the card with 'exFAT' but also somehow seen to include an 'offset' of 16MB at the beginning of the card which show up a 16MB unallocated region in the initial sector on this card under window disk management tool.The solution is to get rid of that 'unallocated' 16MB partition on the card. You could do it in PC but that might require some window command line experience and using 'diskpart' utility and what not and I do not want to confuse people here with that process. For most novice user The process should be very simple, Just insert the card on the tablet and use the 'native' SD Card format tool under 'settings' that Android OS 4.1.1 ha and it will get rid of that 16MB partition and happily remount it. Now after this simple process the 'MTP' application work just fine with PC to transfer file to the SD card without any strange reboot phenomenon.Not sure why SANDISK format their Class 10 card in this fashion (They never did it with their class 6 card earlier) and there's gotta be some technical explanation for why they include that 16MB partition that only SANDISK can give. In the end if you reformat the card in the tablet (Which default to exFAT) the card is seen to work just fine.Bottomline:-----------This is an awesome 64GB capacity MicroSD card from a reputed manufacturer for budget minded people and get the job done beautifully. The read and write speed are adequate enough for most Audio,Video & picture file format in a tablet. The glitch mentioned above forced me to give *Four* star instead of *Five* star but let that not stop you from making a decision to buy it.Highly recommended!Cheers!

I've had this memory card in my S3 for the past few month without any issues. The only problem I've had with this wa when I initially copied the 30GB of data from my old card to this card. I had this connected to my laptop using a MicroSD USB adapter and the copy kept failing. I figured out that the card wa overheating when writing a lot of data. I wa able to copy the data by pointing a small desk fan towards the card adapter during the file copy process. That being said, I don't have any read/write problem due to overheating with the card installed in my phone. I've copied over a couple of gig of movie to watch on some trip with the card installed in the phone without any failures. It may be that heat issue only occurs after pushing >3GB of data at a time. The largest movie I copied to the phone wa 2GB. Most of the other movie are just over a gig.The only prep work for use in my phone wa the initial format when it wa first installed. The card wa recognized prior to the formatting but I had seen where others had read/write issue so the format wa a preemptive move.

This SanDisk UHS-1 TF Card is in good quality.However, it is not working a fast a the Class 10 standard. For operating a series of 4KB files, it can only read at ~2.6MB/s and write at 1.5MB/s.Compared to the SAMSUNG UHS-1 microsd, the SAMSUNG UHS-1 card can at least process 5MB of 4KB file per second, either reading or writing. For reading/writing giant files, This Sandisk card can reach >30MB/S for reading and >15MB/s for writing, which is acceptable for this price, but still a bit lower than SAMSUNG.

The description is quite confusing - it say at same time class 10, which mean that you should not expect write speed higher than 10mb/sec, and at the same time, it say UHS-1, which mean 30mb/sec write speed. The truth, a usually, is somewhere in the middle, but close to lower end. I have a dedicated, high speed PCI-E cardreader, which I use for chip benchmarking. So, this card showed 12mb/sec sequental write speed and 34mb/sec sequental read speed. So, UHS-1 is "true" only for read operations, meaning that if you wanted this card to speed-up your digital camera speed photography - you've made the wrong choice. Just for reference, this cardTranscend 16 GB Class 10 microSDHC Flash Memory Card TS16GUSDHC10has sequental write speed of 17mb/sec and sequental read speed of 24mb/sec. As you see, the cheaper transcend ha average 40% faster write speeds!

This review is for the SanDisk Ultra 32 GB MicroSDHC Class 10 UHS-1 Memory Card with Adapter (SDSDQU-032G-AFFP-A) that wa purchased for me from Amazon.FRUSTRATING in a word. This card wa reported by two different Android phone a damaged but my Windows computer recognized it with no issues. If the card had nothing on it or had just been reformatted then the phone recognized it but a soon a data, music or picture were added then the phone reported the card a damaged. I had this card returned to Amazon after 3 day of sheer frustration.I read another review that suggested the Class 10 card were not ideal for smart phones. I wa already using a Sandisk Class 4 16GB card in another phone and had never had issue so I purchased a Class 4 Sandisk 32GB and it wa a smooth a butter. Both phone recognized the card right away and added data, music and picture seamlessly and quickly. The second card purchased wa the SanDisk microSDHC 32GB Flash Memory Card, Black, SDSDQM-032G-B35 (Retail Packaging).In summary this card may work just fine for other device but based on the sheer number of other reviewer (here on Amazon and elsewhere on the internet) that had similar issue with smartphones I cannot recommend this card for a smartphone.
This is what I needed for my tablet and it work great. I will buy two the next time. thank you .
There is nothing really to say except that I love having this much storage and not having to worry about running out.

I finally have enough room for everything. I formatted my 64gb Sandisk micro SD card using EaseUS Partition Master 9.2.1 Home Edition. I used the FAT32 format. My T-Mobile Prism phone read the card giving me 59.47 gb free. My Samsung Galaxy 2 7.0 tablet read it the same way. I am very happy that any of my device will read this card when I format it a FAT32. There is enough room to hold my my entire CD collection (300 cds), my entire book collection (250+ books), and my entire collection of sermon (I lost count). I still have 23gb left!!! I am too happy. Bottom line, folks, if my cheap android phone will read it, so will everything else. Who need cloud drive and streaming when you can take it with you!!!! Thank God for Sandisk, I am hoping someone come up with 128gb soon. hahaha!

I wa very excited to buy this card (64 gb) for my Samsung Galaxy Note 2 - The product arrived promptly and I wa able to format it to EX Fat and use it right away in my smart phone. However, exactly 10 day later when I removed the card (after turning off the phone) and inserted it in my Desktop, I got an error saying that the card wa corrupted and unreadable and that I needed to format it.Since I had already got a lot of data on it, including a lot of video and image of our new-born twins, formatting wa not a viable option.I tried to get the card working on my PC Desktop, Mac Air laptop and the Samsung Galaxy Note, but to no avail. Finally I decided to format it. There too, I kept getting error and that the computer wa unable to format the card. Finally I tried "Full Format" via my pc - got an error again and then right away "Quick Format" and that worked - so the card is back and working in my Note again, but now I wont trust it anymore - not after having lost so many irreplaceable image and videos.I am a professional photographer, and use memory card all the time - this ha been the worst of the lot !!

I used this for my Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7.0 . Like the others are saying, it had to be formatted in Fat 32. You can put your apps on your SD card with an app called "Link2SD". There are a number of MicroSD manufacturer out there that offer large capacity card like this. They claim to be Class 10 but when tested, prove to be closer to Class 6 card in performance. This SanDisk card performs at the Class 10 level.I use these card in various device that NEED Class 10 speeds, such a my Android phone because of the data transfer I do for work and for the game I keep on it.If your device doe not need Class 10 (you are just using it for simple storage of basic file like doc or ebooks) then you could probably save some money by going with Class 6. If the price are very close, then you might a well spend the extra money and get Class 10.This card came with a nice plastic storage case and a SD adapter. The only reason I gave this 4 star is because I feel the price should be a lot lower by now. Inventory is plentiful and these are not cutting edge tech any more.
My only gripe is I wish it were a bit cheaper, but you never need something like this when it's on sale.

i bought this for only one use, to put in my samsung galaxy s3. i popped in the card, mounted and formatted in settings, and it work like a charm in the phone. HOWEVER(it's in cap pay attention!), when i took it out of the phone and put the microSD into the SD adapter and plugged into the sd card slot on the front of my pc(win7 x64) it asked to format the card(was already formatted by phone so wa confused) so i hit ok, no biggie, it wa empty anyways. window did it thing and when it wa "ready to use" it said the card wa only 1MB(it showed 59.47GB in the phone). so my troubleshooting section of mind kicked in and i removed the card, and i just so happen to have a microSD slot in my computer's frontal bay and it wouldn't even show it wa connected in window explorer. so i took it out and put in another microsd card, voila it read, switched them out again, and nothing. so i decided to pull up my paragon hard disk utility, and it showed the same thing a windows, regardless how i tried formatting it. i gave up and put it back in the phone and mounted it.my s3 said it neded to be formatted. so i formatted it in the phone again and it showed just like it did the first time, 59.47GB. i then proceeded to install samsung ky and got my phone hooked up to my pc via usb cable, i opened the phone in window explorer and right there it show the phone memory at ~16gb and the sd card at 59.47 gb....i'm not quite sure what's going on with that, because the sd slot in my pc read my other card just fine. but anyway i guess if you plan on using it in your phone or possibly other device exclusively because i can use it like a charm while it's in my phone, otherwise it seems pretty useless. so i guess just depends on what you're using it for. on a side not, be careful when you open the plastic package that contains the micro sd and sd adapter, be sure to open it over a large clear area, i opened it up the the living room with black tile floor and had to get a flashlight to find it when it jumped out on the holder(it just set in the little plastic holder so even the slightest shake will send it flying when opening) i'm giving it 3/5 on here, but 5/5 if you're getting it for a phone, galaxy s3 at least because it work fine in mine

I own a first generation Microsoft Surface Pro 128, and it ha been a good machine but I wa really finding it challenging working within the constraint of 128GB of storage space. I had a 64GB Class 10 SDXC card, which worked well but wa not going to fit the VMWare virtual machine I wanted to run off the SD storage. The Virtual Machine increase in size with regular use, and the operating system I wa running is recommended for at least 40GB of max storage to operate properly. Combined with the file I needed to store, and 64GB memory chip wa no longer sufficient.The SanDisk Ultra 128GB MicroSDXC Class 10 Memory Card wa able to handle that with ease, however I have found that the virtual machine ran noticeably faster off the 64GB chip than this one. I've actually ordered a second of these to see if I might have just received a flawed chip. If the replacement chip offer improvement I will revise this review. It provides it main selling point, more storage at a relatively low cost, so far ha run reliably in my tablet computer.If storage space is a significant issue for your device and the memory can make use of 128GB SDXC, then I would recommend product.

64GB is pretty good size, and in a cell phone, it's awesome. However, getting it formatted a FAT32 is not the easiest method. By default, Windows 7 will not allow anything larger than 32GB to be formatted a FAT32. Even if you execute a DOS command to format to FAT32, it will fail. There is a fix though. Ridgecrop Consultants Ltd ha a program that can be downloaded. I would suggest that you support this free application by sending the guy a few bucks, a he ha truly written a great program that work very well in Windows 7. I have used his program, "fat32format" to successfully format this 64GB MicroSDXC disk. I then copied all of my content from my old 12GB disk to this one. I inserted the disk into my phone, and whalla! It work great! Very pleased with this purchase.

NOTE: please read the last update (scroll to the bottom) - I'm leaving this review a 1 star a it appears to help others who purchased and had a similar experience.I give SanDisk 5 star for customer service and 1 star for the product (for those manufactured in the past) For those newly manufactured product that contain the software ROM fix, I'd give the product 5 stars.To all those who purchased this card due to all the great reviews.... and then used it in a Galaxy S4 (GS4) smartphone for storage, the solution to the problem is not one you can solve without returning the card to SanDisk for a replacement under warranty. Believe me I tried everything that the Google search returned a solutions... formatting a exFAT, formatting in the GS4 then copying data to the card while in the phone etc.... nothing worked... and so now please stop pulling out your hair and hopefully you will get the same result which I hope to get soon (just RMA'd and will send it back tomorrow for a free replacement under warranty).The problem (As confirmed from the SanDisk customer support rep when I asked specifically asked him):- When used in the GS4, this card will unmount itself inadvertently (may be true only for card manufactured before the ROM patch described below wa implemented in manufacturing). This can cause the data to become corrupt (luckily wa not my experience) and / or can be very frustrating a most of u are saving 13 MP camera picture to the card (or MP4 movie that stop in the middle of the movie) and it unmounts when you view the picture in the gallery or worse, right when you take the picture (this wa the issue I experienced).- SanDisk know about this issue. Again, SANDISK KNOWS ABOUT THE ISSUE AND WILL REPLACE YOUR CARD. Call them (info below) and they WILL take care of it under warranty. They have a good name for a reason and they want to keep it. (sorry SanDisk about the 1 star, but I thought it wa the way to get the message out to those searching for a solution)- The customer rep told me that SanDisk tried to work with Samsung to resolve the issue but Samsung refused to acknowledge a problem exists with this card and some of their phone (especially their flagship GS4 phones).- The customer rep told me that to their knowledge the card work fine in regular camera (not Samsung GS4 phone with cameras, obviously) and even worked fine in some phone from HTC etc. that could accommodate the 64 GB cards. Hence the 5 star rating from others.- The solution SanDisk came up with wa to write a patch into the ROM of the card itself to specifically address the issue on Samsung GS4 phone (and maybe other Samsung phone like the GS3). I wa assured that the new card I would get would work flawlessly. will see in about 3 weeks.- I purchased my card from Amazon June 2013, so the one currently being manufactured and the one I should get will have the new patch. However, a SanDisk manufacture in batch (like most of the industry), old batch of "unpatched" card obviously exist in warehouses.- I asked about a software patch I could download and wa told it's not possible... hence the "hard coded patch" in the card's ROMSo... how to take care of the problem....After speaking with the SanDisk US customer support (link and info below), this is what I learned and did.Go to the SanDisk site1) [...]2) call consumer product support (this is the US no.) 1-866-SANDISK (726-3475)3) Tell them that the card is unmounting itself in your GS4 (I assume this is also a problem experienced by GS3 owner too)4) They will then confirm your information, approve your return (10-15 min approval window by mine wa basically instantaneously), and then send you email with a UPS return label and instructions.5) BTW, they also asked if I had a magnifying glass to ID the serial no. on the card, but I didn't and couldn't read it myself (those number are super small printed into the plastic... don't believe me? take a look yourself.) I told the rep I couldn't read them and he said no problem, they would process without the serial no. I assume this is because they send you a new replacement card only when they receive your card you send in. Makes sense.Well, that's it. Problem (hopefully) solved. Let's see in 2-3 weeks. The rep wa super nice about it and seemed like they were all too familiar with the problem. KUDOS TO SANDISK FOR TAKING CARE OF IT... however, it would be nice if there wa some type of communication / notice of the issue besides Google info sources, forum etc. I spent hours, maybe a couple of day total hour worth, thinking it wa an issue with my phone / my data transfer. oh well, that's how it goes.I really hope that this review help some of you out there with the same problem a me. GOOD LUCK!!(btw, I'd give the card 5 star if this problem wa solved in the patched ROM of newer card a the data transfer speed are awesome on the card (tested transferring data via a card reader hooked to my computer)... if the data transfer / remaining mounted in the GS4 issue never existed (pre-patch of ROM, of course))UPDATE: 08/17/2013 - All went well with the return of the SanDisk Storage card. UPS shipping took about 2 day from when I sent it, SanDisk verified the warranty claim 1 day later and 5 hour later that same day, my replacement card had been shipped. waiting on the new card now, but expect to test it out very soon (early next week). will update the post after testing out the new card. Just a a reference, I've been using a 32GB Micro SD HC SanDisk card in the GS4 since having shipped the 64GB card. Obviously it's a different card and not the Micro SD XC kind. Other than a bit slower access speed to the card, absolutely zero problems.... well if you don't count that it's basically filled up, hence why the 64GB option is great on the GS4. So it prof the point on the problem with the early build Micro SD XC 64GB cards.I'm happy to see that my review ha helped some others out there. Good luck to you in your warranty claim. my experience with SanDisk customer support ha been excellent so far.Update: 08/21/2013 - Received the new replacement SanDisk Storage card just a few day ago (shipping back to me once they agreed it wa defective wa a very short time window). Have had it running in the Galaxy S4 for a few day now without any jumps, stutter or card unloading in the middle of picture or video taking. Card seems to work flawlessly a the SanDisk Rep mentioned it would. One would think it's such a short time to test after a few day of use, but if this were not fixed already it would have dismounted in the first 45 minutes... that's how often and how fast it wa occurring. so it would seem the problem is solved. The new SD card make the phone even more responsive when moving between picture in the gallery and performing other task like copying file to the card. Thanks SanDisk! Unless I update this review by next week, you will know that the problem ha been fixed.Good luck to those with similar problem a we now know how to get it fixed thanks to SanDisks great responsive customer service.Update: 08/31/2013 - This is the last update to this review just to "close the loop". The new replacement card from SanDisk ha been running flawlessly for about 2 week now. I have not experienced any of the initial problems. SanDisk really did fix the issue in the new batch of cards.Update: 12/09/2013 - The card ha been running in my GS4 flawlessly since replacing it around Aug 21st. Pretty good track record so far (~ 3.5 months) so it appears to be fixed with the newly manufactured (replacement) cards.For those that have left comment that I should change the rating upwards now that the issue is fixed (see my addition at the beginning of this review)... When searching for a solution to a problem with a purchased product, most people start at the 1 star review to see what others have experienced. This is especially true for product with a lot of review (this is what I did in the beginning with this product). Therefore I think leaving it at 1 star and adding the comment at the beginning should clarify the review.Thanks to review commenter "Da Shocker" for his input. I think he sum it up very well when it come to the value of file stored on medium like this:"One more thing.. to those not happy with the one star rating by this person go ahead buy one. Take ton of pic vids and save some music on there then when the card crash come back and give it a five star. A card cost $50-$100 picture from a vacation or family event are priceless.. "

With most of the world's electronic device finally standardizing to SD (thank you Sony for finally adopting this standard), it seems most thing we own work on either the microSD or regular SD card. That's why this little package is so handy. You get both in one neat little package and at 64GB, you'll have plenty of space to store most of your programs, files, etc on your device.The Class 10 rating (ability to move data on/off card at the current maximum speed) is a must for anyone that doesn't want to sit for vital second waiting for data to write to the card. And SanDisk ha proven themselves over the year a making a quality product. Sure, you may occasionally find a dud in their inventory, but they are quick to fix/replace it and that is what matter most. Buying cheaper card will land you with a read/write error when you can least afford it. Don't be the person that loses those important family photo or that document that is due today because of a cheap and defective card.I purchased this particular card for my Asus Transformer, a it fit nicely into the pad itself - and with the optional keyboard attachment (which is capable of holding standard SD cards) it fit there a well. I ordered these card at a great price during black friday week/weekend. I began loading some file (music, videos, pics, etc). The first card worked without any problems. The second card started giving me cyclic redundancy errors. At first, I thought it wa my hard drive that wa failing, and tried to copy the same file to a flash drive which worked just fine. Ok, maybe I received a dud, and tried with another card from my purchase. Same results, cyclic redundancy error. I started searching online, and found a utility via one of the review on Amazon called H2testw. Ran the test on both cards, and it reported errors. It also reported write speed of only 4MB/sec, which is way below advertised speeds. These item were in retail packaging, and I remember reading about the bulk package item being fakes. I guess the retail package card aren't any better.I should have waited to do the refund because now I have to process the refund seperately. I will test another card to see if I have better luck. I wanted to leave a 1 star, but I gave 2 star since 1 card worked so far. I have 2 more to test.Very dissapointed because I wa a fan of the Sandisk Ultra series for being reliable, but I guess they are cheaping out on quality to increase their profit. I would have been extremely upset if I used these card for anything important.

So I got this SD specifically for my GoPro Black 3+, simply hoping it would work since the GoPro manual say "use card up to 64gb" and the SanDisk say it's good for cell phone and tablets, yet doesn't mention the GoPro.Well, turn out it work perfect! And although I haven't tried it on other devices, I think if it work flawlessly on the GoPro, it will work even better on anything else...So at first I thought maybe since it's only 30mbps there may be frame rate issue with recording (even though I knew that shouldn't be the case). Well after popping it in, the GoPro say 9hr14min (1080p super view video) which is insane. I put it on my helmet and took it for a spin. When I came home after spending the day on the bike, the HD quality wa spectacular (granted it's all thanks to the camera itself), but it wa smooth, with zero frame rate issues. The only flaw is the semi long time it take to copy file to your hard drive a it copy at only 30mbps, but honestly that's really no big deal and totally worth it still.Bottom line, this SD plus the GoPro 3+ is the best camera combination for your money.P.S.
