Once you cut and pry your way through Sandisk's packaging, you will be rewarded with a nicely-made and high-performing MicroSD UHS1 flash memory. It come formatted to SD.org's standard in FAT32, so it's ready to go for most applications. My single gripe about this product is that they have omitted the usual small plastic box that hold the card and adapter. I use those! Since I frequently switch card between uses, and frequently have them in storage, those little box are very useful. It's way too easy to lose a MicroSD.Anyway, here are the result from ATTO disk benchmark:Settings (anticipating digicam use): Total length 64MB Overlapped I/O and QD=4 (but it never exceeds 1)Segment Size in Kbytes, Read/Write in Kbyte/secSize Write Read.5 9904 163431 14555 170332 13454 273244 14194 353378 15065 3985316 14154 4062932 14277 4295764 13212 44291128 17567 44247256 16209 44442512 15391 444421024 17408 444422048 16229 44442[Sorry for the ugly table, Amazon doe not support consecutive spaces, including alt-255, or embedded tabs]This is very fast for a MicroSD. It's not quite up to what Sandisk achieves in full size UHS1 SD card that can write over twice this speed, but those are electronically more complex cards. The Micro form factor likely doesn't permit the additional hardware to achieve speed comparable to the larger cards. Note that the read speed is a lot faster than what Sandisk promises. (Note also that you will NOT achieve these speed with a USB2 reader. You will need either a USB3 or built-in PCIe reader to get accurate results. So do not complain to me if you use a USB2 reader and don't achieve these speeds.)In any event, you'd be hard-pressed to find anything faster.My personal experience with Sandisk product is very good. That is, I've never had anything fail on me. Given the very reasonable price of these, I rate them a Highly Recommended.

Maybe there is nothing that can be done and it is just the way the technology is at this time, but to me it seems that the 64GB SD card have very limited us at this time because they are formatted in whats called "exFAT32" instead of the standard FAT32 to get 64GB from a 32GB card. After receiving my card and inserting it into my new android tablet with, Jelly Bean, it wa recognized and it did show I had 59GB available. I then removed the card from the tablet and inserted it into my computers, a Win7 and a Vista, and tried to transfer files, photo and video from my laptop to the card they WOULD NOT TRANSFER! After some research on the internet it appeared that the card had to be reformatted from the new "exFAT32" to the standard FAT32. All my file were created in Win XP and Win Vista - FAT32. I also have a Win7 machine I recently purchased and can easily move all type of file between all the machine and memory card and flash drive but could not transfer any file to this card from any computer a long a the card wa formatted in exFAT32. I had read on the internet about reformatting the card and it working. My Win7 machine doe not even have the option to format to standard FAT32, it only ha NSTF and exFAT32. My older computer have the older FAT32 format option and it took my Vista computer with a Dual Core processor 1 hour to reformat the card to FAT32. After reformatting I wa able to easily transfer my files, photos, and video on my XP and Vista computer BUT not the Win7 computer. The card work in my tablet and I am able to access and use all the file I transferred to the card in FAT32 with my Vista computer on the tablet. BUT after reformatting it now the card only ha 27GB of space available, so it wa essentially reformatted the 64GB card into a 32GB card. I will keep the card because I have a lot of work into it reformatting and transferring file and hopefully in the future I can reformat it again back to exFAT32 if and when exFAT32 catch on and an OS is made that can seamlessly use file created in both FAT32 and exFAT32. This seems to be a good card that work well in certain situation but my advice do your research on what you have and how you will use the card because this is not simply a big GB card that can be used for everything in every device, unless ALL your files, photos, and video are in, or will be created with, exFAT32 there are some real draw back to this card and you might be better off just buying multiple lower GB card if you really need this much storage space in a Micro SD card. Or perhaps card you already own can be reformatted into exFAT32 and double the capacity if your computer ha the exFAT32 reformat option. I have not tried it but based on my experience the last few day it seems like it would work if exFAT32 work for you. I gave 3 star because it doe work, but I feel Sandisk not fully explaining how they are getting 64GB out of this card and the possible problem a consumer might have with it is misleading advertising.

There is a speed penalty if exfat is used a oppose to NTFS.Using ATTO and formatted a exfat:read speed = ~45MBswrite speed = ~15MBsUsing ATTO and formatted a NTFS:read speed = ~45MBswrite speed = ~17MBsWith exfat, the write speed actually fluctuates a the transfer size increases. But using NTFS, the speed are consistent.Tested on Lenovo T530 using built in SD card reader.

I bought three of these and all three worked upon initial installation with no formatting. These speed are much slower than the stated maximum by the card manufacturer, but would be expected with over 12,000 small file like my example. The read / write time were close to 50% faster than those of my old 8 Gb class 10 SanDisk micro SD card, so there is definitely a performance gain with this updated card.All thing considered, 16 Gb of storage on a Class 10 card from the leading manufacturer, and at $15 is a steal. I highly recommend this card.

Monday, November 26, 2012I put this in the Galaxy S3 without formatting, restarted the phone and it showed 59.4g GB of space. I transferred all the file from the old 16 GB card and then moved all my music to the card with the phone connected to my computer by the USB cord. Still lot of space left and the various music player seem to see all the music.Tuesday, November 27, 2012The card didn't show up on the phone this afternoon. No message, just no song to play and no card according to everything I could check on the phone. I restarted the phone and got a notification that the SD card wa corrupt, needed formatting and that I would loose all data on the card. I restarted the phone again, without formatting, and the card came up like it had never been missing. I am writing this on Thursday, 11/29 and I have not had another issue with the card.December 6Well, I don't know what to think. The card disappeared again and I reformatted it FAT32 in an attempt to fix the problem. The whole point of getting this large card wa to have my music on my phone and not have to stream it from the cloud. I tried several music player and went with PowerAmp because of the good review and that I could specify the folder to play from. So PowerAmp is looking for the folder /mnt/extSdCard/Music and playing the song in all the subfolders. It is PowerAmp that tell me that folder is not available.The card ha gone missing one other time and restarting the phone fixed the problem.Today, PowerAmp would not play and when I got home I found the Music folder wa gone. I also had Ringtones folder and it wa also gone. Now, I may not be the sharpest saw in the shed, but I know I did not delete those folders. The card had other folder but not those two so it had not been reformatted.I am starting to think the problem is with the Galaxy S3. I had a 16 GB FAT32 card in this phone that had been in my previous HTC phone. That card wa not large enough to held my music so I don't know if it wa disappearing or not. I wish this combination of phone and 64GB card wa more reliable but just don't know where the problem lies.I lowered the star from 4 to 3 but I really don't know if the problem is with the card, the phone or both. All I know is that they do not seem to be playing well together.December 7There wa a notification on the phone this morning that the SD card wa corrupted and needed to be formatted. I restarted the phone several time and got the notification each time. I reformatted the SD card using the phone, a step I don't think I have tried yet.December 8Another MINOR problem I have is that the message counter get stuck on 1 when I have no new messages. The only fix I have found is to restart the phone. That happened this morning and I got the corrupted card message again, but restarted again and the card came up OK.December 11So, the file on the card keep disappearing. The card is mounted and the phone show the correct free memory but PowerAmp, and file directory program do not see any file on the card. I restart the phone and the file come back. Very strange. I played music on and off all day today without a problem and then this evening all the file disappeared again. Restarted the phone and all is well again.December 15My phone upgraded to 4.1.1 yesterday and the same issue remain. It is a crap shoot a to if music will play. I take a lot of photo and use the service Zenfolio to store and display them. I have an app that syncs with Zenfolio and keep a phone size version of the photo on my phone. I set this app to store the photo on the Samsung SD card and have similar issue with it when the data on the phone go away. This morning the SD card came up a corrupt again after a restart to get the data back. It took a total of 3 restarts to get the music and photo back.December 18I have been trying to play music stored on this card today and my phone ha reset several times. Very frustrating. I ordered a SanDisk 32 GB Mobile microSDHC Flash Memory Card SDSDQ-032G-AFFP today for about $25.00 and I'll see if I have the same issues. Very disappointing.December 28I purchased and installed theSanDisk 32 GB Mobile microSDHC Flash Memory Card SDSDQ-032G-AFFPand copied all the file from the 64GB card to the new 32GB card. No formatting, no fuss, no muss. I have not had a phone reset since, have played music through Bluetooth for hour in the car, have viewed photos. Everything just works. Half the memory but what I have is always available and the phone works, a good trade off. I am still disappointed that the 64GB did not work with the SG3. I have purchased aelago Mobile Nano II USB 2.0 microSDHC Flash Memory Card Reader (Black)to use the 64GB MicroSDHC card a a thumb drive.

Hi:I ordered two card and they arrived the next day, even faster than Prime. Unfortunatey, this 64gb MicroSD card is designed to only work with ex-fat. If you're an ex-fat fan and don't ever plan to change, this is the card for you. I've been able to take all of the previous 64gb MicroSD card I've ordered, put them in an adapter and format them in my Windows 7 desktop. I'm a NTSF fan and find it to be much more stable in tablets.With other card that aren't intentionally crippled, I can format the card to NTSF on Monday, ex-fat on Tuesday, Fat32 on Wednesday. It's ex-fat or the highway for SanDisk.You can use EaseUS Partition Master to format the card to Fat32 for device such a camera and mp3 player and many, many, many others that don't support ex-fat. That being said, you only get one shot. Once it's formatted into Fat32, attempting to format back to Exfat or NTSF hose the card. I couldn't reformat to NTSF no matter what I tried. Once again, don't bother trying to format in your computer, ex-fat is the only choice.Any card that need a special utility to format to anything other than ex-fat shouldn't be supported. Don't buy it! It's designed to fail.Shame on you Sandisk!Update 9/24/12:***************************I spoke with Sandisk technical support and they confirmed that Sandisk Ultra 64gb MicroSd card are not compatible with Android 4.0 and above. This would be for Class 10, SanDisk Ultra 64 GB microSDXC Class 10 UHS-1 Memory Card 30MB/s with Adapter SDSDQUA-064G-U46A a well a SanDisk 64GB Mobile Ultra MicroSDXC Class 10 UHS-1 30MB/s Memory Card with SD Adapter (NEW VERSION) - Retail Packaging with Komputerbay SDXC USB Reader.I did not have any success formatting the class 10 card with EaseUS Partition Master. SanDisk recommended the free utility, HPUSBDISK.exe and I successfully downloaded it from Softpedia. I wa unable to format the card with NTSF but successfully converted one of the card to Fat32 for a friend who want to use it in a SanDisk mp3 player, that of course is not compatible with ex-fat.Acting on Sandisk advice I am returning the unopened class ten card with the KomputerBay reader. I spoke with a patient and gracious tier-one tech support person and the party line seems be that consumer only use MicroSD card in phones. I don't know what they're thinking: cameras, mp3 players, tablets, adapter and so on. Anyway it's a known issue.I can confirm that the class 6 64gb MicroSD card can be formatted in Windows7 back and forth to most any format so after returning four class 10 cards, I'm back to class six.It's still unconscionable to deliberately design these card to be incompatible. I hope SanDisk will come up with a solution or recall the cards. Buyer beware.Update: 9/29/12**********************I received my two replacement class 6, 64gb MicroSD card and it took le than five minute to open the horrible packaging and to perform a quick format to NTSF. Done!I gave my friend the Class 10 64gb MicroSD card formatted into Fat32 by HPUSBDISK.EXE and he couldn't read it on his computer. As it turn out, the class 10 card are not only incompatible with most device bur also with most usb card readers. Another trip across town.I can confirm that the IOGEAR SD/MicroSD/MMC Card Reader/Writer GFR204SD (Green/Gray) selling on Amazon for $6.99 works. So after countless hour of wasted effort, my friend ha a card formatted to Fat32 that work with a SanDisk mp3 player.Once again, SanDisk ha admitted that these card are not compatible with Androd 4.0 or above, that being 100% of Android tablet and a majority of Android phones. These card are intentionally crippled by design.To quote a friend:"Per the SDHC standard, the format is FAT32. SDXC (64 GB and larger) the spec call for exFAT. Microsoft ha limited the OS to only format larger card a exFAT and will not allow FAT32. Also, seems they have found a way to also block NTFS. Thus far, very few Android device can read exFAT because they refuse to pay M$ for licensing of the exFAT file system. "To all masochist out there--buy this card. To everyone else--unsafe at any speed.

I ordered two 32GB and two 64Gb version of these memory card (but I can write only one review per Amazon). Two 32GB card went into a camera and a cell phone which only accept up to 32GB card -- and one 64GB card went into my Samsung Galaxy S3 cell phone. The second 64GB card's a spare.The Galaxy S3 phone accepted the 64GB MicroSD card with no problem -- except for the fact that my Galaxy S3 only recognizes 59.7GB of the 64GB MicroSD card. I have no idea why it doe that and why I lost over 5GB of an empty MicroSD card but I'm okay with that -- I guess. 60GB's is still plenty. The transfer of music, videos, and picture between the phone's internal 16GB memory and the 64GB MicroSD card is wayyy faster than the old SanDisk 16GB MicroSD card that wa in there. The same noticeably faster speed between my desktop computer and the 64GB MicroSD card were also smile inspiring.As for the SanDisk MicroSD card -- they work great and seem to operate pretty darn fast. They're definitely faster than the old 16GB SanDisk MicroSD card I had installed in my camera and cell phone(s).Now -- a for the shipping -- dismal! I ordered two 32GB along with two 64GB MicroSD card on August 21 during an Amazon Gold Box sale. According to the tracking feature they didn't even transmit the shipping info to the carrier (USPS) until August 31. All four were shipped together. I didn't receive them until September 6 -- a full 16 day after I ordered. A little over two week for four tiny item that were indicated on the Amazon page a being -- "In Stock. Ships from and sold by Amazon.com" -- at the time of purchase. They also shipped all four tiny MicroSD card package in a way over-sized box which the USPS couldn't fit into the mailbox so I had to make a cross-town trip to the US Post Office and stand in a very long and slow moving line to pick up the box. They could have all four EASILY fit in one small envelope. Even a small padded envelope. I left packaging feedback on that already.This is the 3rd straight time that Amazon shipping wa horrible over the last several month -- and that is why the 2-star rating. This is not the Amazon shipping that I remember.

Sandisk announcement of the first 128GB micro SD took internet by storm. Our phone evolved into multimedia powerhouse with 5.5"-6" displays, desktop grade processing power, OTG support for external peripheral accessories, powerful cameras, and more. The only thing wa missing a super high capacity internal removable storage at an affordable price. 128GB micro SD announcement finally filled that gap, supported by amazon current sale of $119 shipped, but the question still remained if some of the older smartphones will be able to handle/recognize this capacity. I wa personally curious considering original Note 2 spec wa calling for support of up to 64GB only.Now, about the card itself. Its their Ultra edition with a read speed of up 30MB/s and Class 10 performance. As part of Ultra edition it's considered to be waterproof, temperature-proof, x-ray-proof, magnet-proof, and also shockproof. In addition to a flash card itself, it also includes SD adapter for compatibility with digital camera and also direct reading on laptops/PCs support SD card.So here come the verdict: IT WORKS with Note 2!!! My Note 2 is all stock, Verizon SCH-I605 version, running stock Android 4.3. I checked the card first with an adapter on my laptop and then mounted it on my Note 2 where it wa recognized with a right capacity. I also ran A1 SD Benchmark app (both long and accurate benchmark tests) to verify it with success. Read/write speed were not quite near 30MB/s, but it's still pretty good.My opinion? This card take multimedia powerhouse Note 2 to the next level!!! Now you don't have to be limited and can store your favorite album in FLAC audio format, or have a small library of your favorite movie stored permanently, or take more high def videos, and so on. Just always stay up to date with backups. If flash card fails, it will be covered under warranty, but your picture and video will be lost forever.

I own the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 10.1I bought the 64g microSD card..(please keep in mind I know NOTHING about computer and I wa able to do this.)I put it in the device to format...the tablet couldn't read it. Would never mount. Tried to format it with my computer....and still just wouldnt work..although it would be formatted. Remember, I wa using all defaults.Sent it back, Amazon sent me another one. (Amazingly fast service)...same thing.I called Amazon...they knew of no issue why my tablet wouldn't accept the card. (I would think that their customer service dept. would stay on top of these post because I found that this wa a HUGE issue)On my THIRD card I did some research. For whatever reason for this SD card to work it must be formatted a a FAT 32 NOT an exFAT. BUT...(this is the rub)...windows only allows for formatting either to exFAT or NTSF...(at first, I thought it wa an adult swim reference).....so....that sucks....this mean that I can't use this card because I can't format it properly. But wait..there's more....there is a super easy fix....any idiot can do it.....from start to finish took me all of 45 second (after reading instructions)...and ta-duh.....now the micro SD card work fine. Thank-you Amazon for your excellent return policy..(super fast, super easy, super friendly)...BUT your live customer service should know about this. I can't fault the operator...she wa nice..seemed genuinely concerned and tried to make it right)...ok.. no more stalling..here is the address of the youtube video. link to website is in the description.[...] ...link to website in description. I used all default and worked perfect. or search youtube - convert fat32

People often ask me about bargain-basement pricing on no-name brand of media, and you know I just have to cite my own experience with cheap media, and it's just that, cheap media, prone to failure or worse if it's a complex format a this one is, the SDXC format. They have crammed a TON of memory module in that little bujgger, you know? I say go with experience, go with a leader in the field, so there's pretty much SanDisk at the top of the heap, and the rest trail far, far behind in volume and precision assembly techniques...so I vote for SanDisk every time, and unless my experience is changed by some anomaly I'll keep on recommending SanDisk above all others.It's rated at 40MB/sec write speed, which is enough to keep up with even the fastest real camera or phone camera out there in the wild, and it certainly keep up with my Samsung Note 3's 13-mega-pixel rocket camera, one that shoot up to 8fps in burst mode taking certain shots, so if it work for that camera perfect, chance are it will work for your setup great also!Buying the SanDisk memory module cost what, $5-$7 more than the others max, right? Most mobile device and tablet that are of any count state that the limit to their sd storage is 32GB...but on a few of those they can and do read sd card that are in fact larger than this. I would suggest anyone that think they need space beyond those stated limit of their device do a quick search on line for their particular MAKE and Model cellphone or tablet to see what size SD's others have been successful at using. Once you have found out and that you can in fact use such an SD...go and search online for HDD Raw Copy Tool from HDD GURU...and it will allow you to make an image of your old SD to apply to the new SD and/or even make a backup of one's SD. Since the SD drive are different size when this image is applied to the larger...you will need to use a partition manager, such a MiniTool partition wizard (which is free for home use) and resize the partition of the larger drive. This will allow you to take advantage of the whole drive space. I love the upgrade and added space...can't go wrong with this price for a class 10 SD of this size.

SO I recently got a new Chinese brand Android phone (Inew i4000): Quadcore, 13mp camera, 1GB ram, 16Gb internal storage + MicroSD Support. Also come with App2SD software support a well.I had an old Samsung Class 10 32GB and tested that it work with the i4000. But wasn't enough for a Power-user like me.Decided to give it the extra storage BOOST!With the Sandisk 64GB Class 10, I now hold within:11GB Music Collection (MP3's at ~192 KBPS)20GB of Graphic Novels/Manga/ManwhaBooks with a Manga App/reader2GB of Apps (migrate the Core apps from internal storage to External storage)8GB of Photos taken with the Phone (uses MicroSD a storage for photos)~30GB of free space left for downloading Movies/MP3s/and document on-the-goI love this little card, it fantastic and a great way to add some serious expandable storage onto any Smartphone that support the storage.FYI, I had to format the Sandisk 64GB card using my Smartphone (i4000) in order for it to set the microSD to FAT32. DON'T use the PC/laptop to do the format, it will mess it up.Was debating between Class 10 Sandisk 64GB or Class 10 Samsung 64GB, I decided to throw my lot in with the 6000+ review for sandisk with an average customer rating of 4.9 Stars. Samsung had 4.9 star but wa from 11 people. So LOL!Highly Recommend this to others!

DO NOT PUT ANY IMPORTANT DATA IN IT. DO NOT USE IT AS A PERMANENT STORAGE TO ARCHIVE IMPORTANT FILES.It just failed after 1.5 month use -- i don't use it too much. Just put all my digital picture (total: about 30GB) in it and carried in my wallet. I added some more picture to the disk for a few time in November. Tonight, when I insert it into my laptop, Windows say cannot recognize the disk and said it must be formatted. I tried my MacBook Air and got the same. Neither Mac nor Windows can read it. I formatted it and started to copy the 30+GB picture again. The copy broke in half way. Cancelled the copy, reinserted the disk and tried to resume the copy. Windows said the volumn is back and told me I must run chkdsk. I ran chkdsk and retried the copy. Still the same failure.I guess the disk ha some problem and I don't bother recovering it, since it's not going to be reliable a I expected. Very disappointed. Thought SanDisk is a very good brand. I use SanDisk's CF card in my camera for year and it worked fine. I will fall back to use hard disk to backup my ditigal pictures.So it should be find to use this microSD disk to exchange some large file with friends. But don't put important data in it. Be prepard that it can fail at any time.
